name: ART adult remain on ART end of period
definition:
Total adults remaining on ART (Adult TROA) at the end of the reporting month are the sum of the following:
-Any adult that has a current regimen in the column designating the month you are reporting on.
-Any adult client that has a star without a circle (someone who is not yet considered loss to follow-up (LTF) in the column designating the month you are reporting on.
Clients remaining on ART equals [naïve (including PEP and PMTCT) + Experienced (Exp) + Transfer in (TFI) + Restart] minus [Died (RIP) + loss to follow-up (LTF) + Transfer out (TFO)]
definitionExtended: NOTE that clients who have an outcome in the specified month or months previous should not be counted in this total
useAndContext: Monitors the total clients remaining on life-long ART at the end of a reporting month
inclusions: None
exclusions: None
tools: ART clinical record captured in TIER.Net, SMARTER

name: ART child cumulative interrupt

definitionExtended: TIER.Net classifies LTF as ITR at the duration following LTF date. A person WILL NOT be counted as both an ITR and as having an ART status (first line, second line, third line or STO) at the same duration – these data elements are mutually exclusive. Where client returns to care the LTF outcome and date is replaced with ITR. Simultaneously the duration at return will also be marked with RTC. Patients who have met the LTF definition but have not returned to care remain classified as LTF

name: CCMDD - new enrolment
definition: All new STABLE patients with chronic diseases enrolled on the Central Chronic Medicines Dispensing and Distribution (CCMDD) programme for the first time, for the current month
definitionExtended: All CCMDD patients who have received a CCMDD chronic prescription and have not been registered on the programme previously. Facility must supply first cycle of medication
useAndContext: New stable patients with chronic diseases enrolled on the CCMDD programme - first cycle of medication supply provided at the facility
inclusions: None
exclusions: If patients clients do not have SA identity, Passport, Asylum seeker number, they are not registered on the programme.
collectedBy: All health establishments that are implementing the CCMDD programme /CDU programmes(Western Cape)

name: CCMDD - renewal
definition: All STABLE patients with chronic diseases with a renewed prescription for the Central Chronic Medicines Dispensing and Distribution (CCMDD)  programme for the current month
definitionExtended: All CCMDD patients who have received a CCMDD chronic prescription and have been registered on the programme previously, including those patients that were dormant and have a renewed CCMDD prescription. Facility must supply first cycle of medication.
useAndContext: Stable patients with chronic diseases re - enrolled on the CCMDD programme - first cycle of medication supply again provided at the facility
inclusions: INCLUDE all patients  that were dormant
exclusions: EXCLUDE patients who do not have SA identity, passport, asylum seeker number, as they are not registered on the programme
collectedBy: All health establishments implementing the CCMDD /CDU programmes(Western Cape)

name: CCMDD client collecting medicine parcel from contracted external PuPs
definition: Central Chronic Medicines Dispensing and Distribution (CCMDD) patients clients who opted to collect their patient medicine parcels from CCMDD contracted external Pick up Points (PuP)
definitionExtended: CCMDD patients registered to collect at contracted External Pickup Points
useAndContext:
The external pick up point must be contracted. To quantify the number of new and renewed patients who have opted to collect their medication from external pick up points.

Patients on CCMDD have various modalities that they can collect their medication from. Patients who choose to collect from an external pick up point, provide the most benefit to the patient, due to convenience and the facility. We therefore monitor how many patients are selecting this option
inclusions: INCLUDE External Pick up Points, all pick up points contracted by the National Department of Health, with an active contract to provide Pick up Point services for CCMDD. This includes all compensated and non remunerated contracts
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Clients collecting at any Pick up Point not contracted by the National Department of Health

EXCLUDE Clients collecting from internal Pick up Points (Internal pick up points include Adherence clubs, outreach PUPs,Community outreach, CCMDD lanes in facility,WBPHCOT where parcels are delivered to facilities (parcels delivered to patients) 

EXCLUDE If unique identification SA identlty, passport, asylum seeker number not available
collectedBy: All health establishments implementing the CCMDD /CDU programmes(Western Cape)

name: Diarrhoea death under 5 years
definition: A child under 5 years who died in a health facility where diarrhoea was documented as the main cause of death (count only the main diagnosis). Where applicable, these deaths must also be counted under SAM deaths and MAM deaths
definitionExtended: Diarrhoea occurs when stools contain more water than normal. Counting separations/deaths due to diarrhoea can be complicated because the condition often coexists with other serious conditions for which data are collected. Where applicable, these deaths must also be counted under SAM deaths and MAM deaths. Count only if diarrhoea was the main cause of death (the main diagnosis). A child can only be recorded as having died from diarrhoea or from pneumonia. The ICD 10 codes are A03, A09.0 and A09.9 .
useAndContext: Monitors the severity and management of diarrhoea in children under 5 years of age.
inclusions: INCLUDE Where applicable, these deaths must also be counted under SAM deaths and MAM deaths (This does not represent double counting as the two data elements should never be added together)
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Under five child  diarrhoea death before admission

EXCLUDE death of child under five but diarrhoea is not recorded as main cause of death

name: Diarrhoea separation under 5 years
definition: Child under 5 years with diarrhoea as main final diagnosis at separation
definitionExtended: The ICD 10 codes are A03, A09.0 and A09.9 . Diarrhoea occurs when stools contain more water than normal. Counting separations/deaths due to diarrhoea can be complicated because the condition often coexists with other serious conditions for which data are collected, in particular in children with HIV/AIDS
useAndContext: Monitors the severity and management of diarrhoea in children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE all children with severe acute malnutrition, moderate acute malnutrition or no acute malnutrition
exclusions: None

name: Diarrhoea with dehydration new in child under 5 years
definition: Child under 5 years diagnosed with diarrhoea with some or severe dehydration (IMCI definitions)
definitionExtended: Diarrhoea occurs when stools contain more water than normal. Mothers usually know whether their children have diarrhoea. Dehydration is present when diarrhoea is accompanied by any 2 of the following: Lethargy or unconscious state, sunken eyes, unable to drink/drinking poorly/not drinking eagerly, pinched skin goes back very slowly, restless/irritable and/or thirsty. Only record children presenting for the first time for the current episode of diarrhoea with dehydration (i.e. new case)
useAndContext: Monitors diarrhoea incidence in children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE referrals from a private general practitioner
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; OPD, Casualties

name: Infant exclusively breastfed at DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV (Hexavalent) 3rd dose
definition: Infant reported to be exclusively breastfed at DTaP-IPV-HepB-HBV (Hexavalent) 3rd dose immunisation (preferably 14 weeks after birth)
definitionExtended: If immunisation is delayed the data item must still be recorded at the time when DTaP-IPV-HepB-Hib is given. Information should be obtained from the mother/caregiver by means of a 24-hour recall on what the infant drank/ate the previous day (ask specifically about water), and not by using a YES or NO, closed ended question. Only record as exclusively breastfed if the child received breastmilk ONLY (the child may have received medicines/vaccines prescribed by a health professional). A child who has received ANY solids, milk (other than breastmilk) or other liquids (including water) should not be counted. All providers that contribute to the number of hexavalent must report on the number of infants exclusively breastfed
useAndContext: Monitors infants on exclusively breastfeeding up till the age of 14 weeks after birth
inclusions: INCLUDE intake of breastmilk only, and only medications approved by health professional for 1st 6 months
exclusions: EXCLUDE intake of water and formula for first 6 months

name: Moderate acute malnutrition in child under 5 years new
definition: Child under 5 years with weight-for-length/height between -2 and -3 Z-score (all U5 children) or with MUAC from 11.5cm to 12.4 cm (among 6-59mo) and no oedema
definitionExtended: A child under 5 years with a weight-for-height between -2 and -3 Z-score and/or child (6-59 months) has a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) from 11.5 to 12.4 cm and no oedema. Only record children presenting for the first time with moderate acute malnutrition (MAM) during this episode (i.e. new cases), not those coming for follow-up. A child previously identified with MAM that was cured (completed nutritional rehabilitation successfully), but who later develops MAM again should be counted again as a new case. Count the child regardless of the cause of MAM
useAndContext: Monitors prevention and diagnosis of moderate acute malnutrition in children under 5 years
inclusions: INCLUDE referrals from a private general practitioner
exclusions: EXCLUDE referrals from other state health facilities since these facilities would have already reported a new case of MAM under -5 years new
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; OPD Register

name: Moderate acute malnutrition death under 5 years
definition: Death in child under 5 years with moderate acute malnutrition (MAM)
definitionExtended:
The ICD 10 code is E44 and E46. The criteria for MAM is:
MUAC (mid-upper arm circumference) 11.5-12.4cm, if over 6 months, OR WHZ (weight for height)-2 and -3 and no oedema. All children under 5 years who were assessed as having MAM on admission must be reported here, irrespective of the cause of death (it does not imply that the child died from MAM)
useAndContext: Monitors the management of MAM in children under 5 years of age
inclusions:
INCLUDE all deaths in children under five years assessed as having MAM

INCLUDE Inpatients only
exclusions: None

name: Moderate acute malnutrition inpatient separation under 5 years
definition: An inpatient under 5 years with moderate acute malnutrition (MAM). This data item is only counted at separation. Count separation of a child under 5 years who was assessed as having MAM on admission
definitionExtended:
The ICD 10 code is E44 and E46. The criteria for MAM is:
MUAC (mid-upper arm circumference) 11.5-12.4cm, if over 6 months, OR WHZ (weight for height) -2 and -3 and no oedema. The nutritional status of all under 5 children must be assessed on admission and recorded as: SAM, MAM or no acute malnutrition. Although the assessment should be done on admission, the data item is only reported at separation
useAndContext: Monitors the management of MAM in children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE all children under five years assessed as having MAM
exclusions: EXCLUDE children with SAM and children with NAM

name: No acute malnutrition inpatient separation under 5 years
definition:
An inpatient under 5 years with no acute malnutrition (NAM)
This data item is only counted at separation. Count separation of a child under 5 years who was assessed as having NAM on admission
definitionExtended:
The criteria for NAM is:
MUAC (mid-upper arm circumference) ≥ 12.5cm, if over 6 months, OR WHZ (weight for height) ≥-2 and no oedema). The nutritional status of all children must be assessed on admission and recorded as: SAM, MAM or NAM. Although the assessment should be done on admission, the data item is only reported at separation
useAndContext: Monitors the management of NAM in children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE all children under five years assessed as having NAM
exclusions: EXCLUDE children with SAM and children with MAM

name: Pneumonia death under 5 years
definition: A child under 5 years who died in a health facility where pneumonia was documented as the main cause of death
definitionExtended:
Pneumonia is defined as cough and fast breathing. The definition of fast breathing depends on the age of the child:
age 1 week up to 2 months: 60 breaths per minute or more = fast breathing
age 2 months up to 12 months: 50 breaths per minute or more
age 12 months up to 5 years: 40 breaths per minute or more. Counting separations/deaths due to pneumonia can be complicated because the condition often coexists with other serious conditions for which data are collected. Count only if Pneumonia was the main cause of death (the main diagnosis). A child can only be recorded as having died from diarrhoea or from pneumonia. Where applicable, these deaths must also be counted under SAM deaths and MAM deaths. The ICD 10 codes are J12-J22,B59, B25.0.
useAndContext: Monitors the severity and management of pneumonia in children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE where applicable, these deaths under SAM deaths and MAM deaths  (this does not represent double counting as the two data elements should never be added together)
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Under 5 child  pneumonia death before admission 

EXCLUDE Child under 5 who died, but pneumonia is not recorded as main cause of death

name: Pneumonia new in child under 5 years
definition: Child under 5 years classified as pneumonia according to the IMCI definition
definitionExtended:
Pneumonia is defined as cough or chest in drawing or stridor in calm child or difficult and fast breathing. The definition of fast breathing depends on the age of the child:
age 1 week up to 2 months: 60 breaths per minute or more = fast breathing
age 2 months up to 12 months: 50 breaths per minute or more
age 12 months up to 5 years: 40 breaths per minute or more. Only record children presenting for the first time with the current episode of pneumonia (i.e. new cases), not those coming for follow-up
useAndContext: Monitors pneumonia incidence in children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE referrals from a private general practitioner
exclusions:
EXCLUDE children under 5 years diagnosed with other respiratory infections

EXCLUDE referrals from other state health facilities, since these facilities would have already recorded a new case of pneumonia under 5 years

definition: Child under 5 years with pneumonia as main final diagnosis at separation
definitionExtended:
The ICD 10 codes are J12-J22, B59, B25.0.

Pneumonia is defined as cough and fast breathing. The definition of fast breathing depends on the age of the child:
age 1 week up to 2 months: 60 breaths per minute or more = fast breathing
age 2 months up to 12 months: 50 breaths per minute or more
age 12 months up to 5 years: 40 breaths per minute or more. Counting separations/deaths due to pneumonia can be complicated because the condition often coexists with other serious conditions for which data are collected, in particular in children with HIV/AIDS.
useAndContext: Monitors the severity and management of pneumonia in children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE all children with SAM, MAM or NAM
exclusions: None

name: Severe acute malnutrition death under 5 years
definition: Death in child under 5 years with severe acute malnutrition (SAM)
definitionExtended: The ICD 10 codes are E40, E41, E42 and E43. A child under 5 years is classified to be severely malnourished if the child has a weight for height/length (WHL) below -3 Standard Deviation scores (<-3SD) and/or presence of bilateral pitting oedema and/or child (6-59 months) has a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) of less than 115mm. The weight-for-age chart in the Road-to-Health Booklet shows body-weight relative to age in comparison to the median (0-line). All children under 5 years who were assessed as having SAM on admission must be reported here, irrespective of the main final diagnosis or cause of death (it does not imply that the child died from SAM). For example, a child who is assessed as having SAM dies from pneumonia, the child should be counted under Pneumonia death under 5 years AND under Death in child under 5 years with severe acute malnutrition (SAM)
useAndContext: Monitors the severity and management of SAM in children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE all deaths in children under five years assessed as having SAM,INPATIENTS ONLY.
exclusions: EXCLUDE children with non-nutritional oedema.

name: Severe acute malnutrition in child under 5 years new
definition: Child under 5 years with weight-for-length/height below -3 Z-score (all U5 children) or with MUAC <11.5 cm (among 6-59mo) or nutritional oedema of both feet (all U5 children)
definitionExtended: Only record children presenting for the first time with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) during this episode (i.e. new cases), not those coming for follow-up. A child previously identified with SAM that was cured (completed nutritional rehabilitation successfully), but who develops SAM again should be counted again as a new case . Count the child regardless of the cause of the severe malnutrition.
useAndContext: Monitors prevention and diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition in children under 5 years.
inclusions: INCLUDE referrals from a private general practitioner
exclusions: EXCLUDE referrals from other state health facilities, since these facilities would have already reported a case of severe malnutrition under 5 years new
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; OPD Register

name: Severe acute malnutrition inpatient separation under 5 years
definition: An inpatient under 5 years with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). This data item is only counted at separation. Count separation of child under 5 years who was assessed as having SAM on admission
definitionExtended: The ICD 10 codes are E40, E41, E42, E43. A child under 5 years is classified to be severely malnourished if the child has a weight for height/length (WHL) below -3 Standard Deviation scores (<-3SD) and/or presence of bilateral pitting (nutritional) oedema and/or child (6-59 months) has a mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) of less than 115mm. The nutritional status of all U5 children must be assessed on admission and recorded as: SAM, MAM or no acute malnutrition (NAM). Although the assessment should be done on admission and recorded in case sheet, the data item is only reported at separation. Even though the child was admitted with diarrhoeal disease or pneumonia, the child must also be counted as having SAM
useAndContext: Monitors the severity and management of SAM in children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE all children under five years assessed as having SAM
exclusions:
EXCLUDE children with non-nutritional oedema;

EXCLUDE children with MAM and NAM

name: Vitamin A dose 12-59 months
definition: Vitamin A dose given to a child, preferably every six months from 12 to 59 months
definitionExtended: Deworming medication must be given together with the Vitamin A. Consisting of a single dose of 200,000 IU. Routine Vitamin A supplementation strengthens the immune system of children. Routine Vitamin A supplementation consisting of a single dose every 6 months until 59 months (4 year 11 months). Children receiving routine multivitamin syrup can still receive routine Vitamin A supplementation. If a child is scheduled to receive a routine prophylactic dose of Vitamin A and has received a treatment dose within the past month, the routine dose should be postponed for one month. Record only the doses given as part of the Vitamin A immunisation schedule. The dose given should also be recorded on the Road to Health booklet. Vit A doses given by WBPHCOTs in households and by school health nurses at schools should be counted
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the Vit A policy for children under 5 years of age
inclusions:
INCLUDE Vitamin A dose given by CHWs as part of community service

INCLUDE Vitamin A given at schools/crèches as part of school health service
 
INCLUDE local mop-up activities
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Vitamin A supplement given as part of a mass national campaigns

EXCLUDE any doses given for therapeutic reasons
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register
OPD Tick register

The nutritional status of all U5 children must be assessed on admission and recorded as: SAM, MAM or no acute malnutrition (NAM). Although the assessment should be done on admission and recorded in case sheet, the data item is only reported at separation. Even though the child was admitted with diarrhoeal disease or pneumonia, the child must also be counted as having SAM.
useAndContext: Monitors the severity and management of SAM in children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE all children under five years assessed as having SAM
exclusions:
EXCLUDE children with non-nutritional oedema

EXCLUDE children with MAM and NAM

name: Vitamin A dose 12-59 months
definition: Vitamin A dose given to a child, preferably every six months from 12 to 59 months
definitionExtended: Deworming medication must be given together with the Vitamin A. Consisting of a single dose of 200,000 IU. Routine Vitamin A supplementation strengthens the immune system of children. Routine Vitamin A supplementation consisting of a single dose every 6 months until 59 months (4 year 11 months). Children receiving routine multivitamin syrup can still receive routine Vitamin A supplementation. If a child is scheduled to receive a routine prophylactic dose of Vitamin A and has received a treatment dose within the past month, the routine dose should be postponed for one month. Record only the doses given as part of the Vitamin A immunisation schedule. The dose given should also be recorded on the Road to Health booklet. VitA doses given by WBPHCOTs in households and by school health nurses at schools should be counted.
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the Vit A policy for children under 5 years of age
inclusions: INCLUDE Vitamin A dose given by CHWs as part of community service; INCLUDE Vitamin A given at schools/crèches as part of school health service; INCLUDE local mop-up activities
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Vitamin A supplement given as part of a mass national campaigns;
EXCLUDE any doses given for therapeutic reasons;

useAndContext: Monitors domestic microbiological water safety. It is used to monitor the safety of water used in residential areas, hospitality industry, food production, water outlets, schools and health facilities amongst other settings. It is key in identifying poor water quality that may lead to occurrences of waterborne diseases. Safe water is a key determinant of health and contribute to the NDP goals of raising the life expectancy of South Africans to at least 70 years, reducing maternal, infant and child mortality

name: BCG dose
definition: BCG (tuberculosis) vaccine given to a child under one year of age at birth. The cut-off age is under 12 months
definitionExtended:
All babies or infants receiving BCG should be counted, including babies coming to clinics after home deliveries and babies or infants who received their BCG later than usual due to e.g. temporary shortages of vaccine. BCG should still be given to HIV exposed children. Tuberculosis (TB) is a mycobacterial disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is a major cause of disability and death in many parts of the world. Do not give BCG vaccine to children who are sick with AIDS and other immunosuppressive conditions. Do not give BCG to a new-born if the mother is on anti-TB drugs. Do not give BCG to a child who is older than 12 months.
For Hospitals: BCG dose under 1 year should be in line with number of live births in the facility
useAndContext: Monitors the Expanded Programme on Immunisation policy
inclusions: INCLUDE BBAs if they are given BCG
exclusions: None
tools: Delivery Register; PHC Comprehensive Tick Register

useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against diphtheria, tetanus, a-cellular pertussis, polio, Haemophilus influenza and Hepatitis B. DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV (known as Hexavalent) was implemented in 2015 to replace DTaP-IPV/Hib (Pentaxim) and HepB
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: Immunised fully under 1 year new
definition: A child who have completed his or her primary course of immunisation before the age of one year.
definitionExtended: The child must have received all primary doses before 12 months of age (BCG; OPV 0 &1; DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV 1, 2 and 3; RV 1 and 2; PCV 1, 2 and 3 & MR 1).  Only doses received before 12 months of age should be counted as fully immunised AND there is documentary proof of all administered primary doses
useAndContext: The child should only be counted ONCE as fully immunised when receiving the last vaccine in the course (usually PCV3 vaccine) AND if there is documented proof of all required vaccines (BCG, OPV1, DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV 1, 2, 3, PCV 1,2,3, RV 1,2 and MR 1) on the Road to Health Card or Booklet AND the child is under 1 year old
inclusions: INCLUDE catch-up doses given to children before 1 year of age
exclusions: EXCLUDE catch-up doses given after 1 year of age

name: MR 1st dose
definition: Measles or Measles Rubella (MR) vaccine 1st dose given to a child under one year of age at 6 months after birth. The cut-off age is under 12 months
definitionExtended: Children under 1 year who received Measles or MR 1st dose, as a proportion of population under 1 year. Both Measles and MR doses will form part of the numerator to ensure accurate coverage of historical data. All children older than 12 months who have missed the 1st dose of MR vaccine at 6 months, should receive this dose immediately and receive the second dose with a 4 week interval. Record dose given on the Road to Health Booklet and Patient Register
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against Measles and Rubella viruses
inclusions: INCLUDE all catch-up doses given to children under 12 months of age
exclusions:
EXCLUDE catch-up doses given to children aged 12 months and above

EXCLUDE doses given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

EXCLUDE children who are sick with HIV AIDS and other immunosuppressive conditions
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register, Hospital paediatric registers

name: MR 2nd dose
definition: Measles Rubella vaccine 2nd dose given to a child at 12 months after birth. The cut-off age is under 24 months
definitionExtended: Children 12 months old who received Measles or MR 2nd dose, as a proportion of the 1 year population. Both Measles and MR doses will form part of the numerator to ensure accurate coverage of historical data. All children aged 24 months and above who have missed the 1st Measles or MR dose at 6 months, should receive this dose immediately and receive the second dose within a 4 week interval. If any child older than 24 months who has not received 1st and 2nd dose of Measles or MR vaccine, the missed doses should be given with an interval of 4  weeks between 1st and 2nd dose and dose(s) should be recorded under the catch-up file and not under routine file of the DHIS. Record dose given on the Road to Health Booklet and Patient Register
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against Measles & MR viruses. Because the 1st Measles & Rubella dose is only around 85% effective the 2nd dose is important as a booster
inclusions: INCLUDE all catch-up doses given to children under 24 months of age
exclusions:
EXCLUDE catch-up doses given to children aged 24 months and above

EXCLUDE doses given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register, Hospital paediatric registers

name: OPV 0 dose under 1 year
definition: Oral polio Vaccine  (OPV) 0 dose given to a child under 1 year at birth. The cut-off age is under 6 months.
definitionExtended: OPV is given together with BCG at birth
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against Polio. Vaccines given as part of mass vaccination campaigns should not be counted here
inclusions:
INCLUDE BBAs if they are given BCG

INCLUDE BBA's if they are given OPV O dose
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register, Hospital paediatric registers

name: OPV 1st dose under 1 year
definition: Oral polio Vaccine 1st dose given to a child under 1 year at 6 weeks. The cut-off age is under 12 months
definitionExtended: OPV 1st is given to children at 6 weeks. OPV 1st dose is given together with RV1, DTaP-IPV-Hib_HBV 1 and PCV1 at 6 weeks
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against Polio
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: PCV 1st dose under 1 year
definition: Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine 1st dose given to a child under 1 year at 6 weeks. The cut-off age is under 12 months
definitionExtended: PCV is given to children at 6, 14 weeks and 9 months. PCV 1st dose is given together with OPV1, DTaP-IPV-Hib_HBV 1 and RV1 at 6 weeks
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against Streptococcus pneumonia.
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: PCV 2nd dose under 1 year
definition: Pneumococcal (PCV) vaccine 2nd dose given to a child under one year, at 14 weeks. The cut-off age is under 12 months
definitionExtended: PCV is given to children at 6, 14 weeks and 9 months. PCV2 is given together with RV2 and DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV 3 at 14 weeks
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against Streptococcus pneumonia.
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: PCV 3rd dose under 1 year
definition: Pneumococcal (PCV) vaccine 3rd dose given to a child under one year, at 9 months after birth. The cut-off age is under 12 months
definitionExtended: PCV is given to children at 6 and 14 weeks and at 9 months. PCV 3rd dose is usually the last vaccine to be given for a child to be fully immunised
useAndContext: Monitors the Expanded Programme on Immunisation policy
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: RV 1st dose under 1 year
definition: Rotavirus (RV) vaccine 1st dose given to a child at 6 weeks after birth. The cut-off age is under 20 weeks.
definitionExtended: RV is given to children at 6 and 14 weeks. RV 1st dose is given together with OPV1, DTaP-IPV-Hib_HBV 1 and PCV1 at 6 weeks
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against Rotaviruses.
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: RV 2nd dose under 1 year
definition: Rotavirus (RV) vaccine 2nd dose given to a child under one year, at 14 weeks after birth and NOT later than 24 weeks after birth.
definitionExtended: If the child missed the 1st dose of RV at 6 weeks of age and is younger than 20 week, give the 1st dose and the 2nd dose 4 weeks later. Keep a minimum interval of 4 weeks between the 2 doses of RV. RV 2nd dose is given together with DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV and PCV
useAndContext: Monitors the Expanded Programme on Immunisation policy
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE vaccines given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

name: Tdap dose at 12 years
definition: Tdap booster dose given to a child at 12 years of age. The cut-off age is 14 years
definitionExtended: Tdap is tetanus plus diluted diphtheria plus acellular pertussis. Do not administer Tdap for children who are younger than 12 years of age
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis including vaccinations done at schools.
inclusions:
INCLUDE doses given during catch-up campaigns to children between 12 and 14 years old

INCLUDE doses given during ‘mopping-up’ campaign
exclusions:
EXCLUDE doses given during mopping –up campaigns conducted as part of mass campaign

EXCLUDE doses given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

EXCLUDE children younger than 12 years
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register, School Health Register, Hospital paediatric registers

name: Tdap dose at 6 years
definition: Tdap booster dose given to a child at 6 years of age. The cut-off age is 9 years
definitionExtended: Tdap is tetanus plus diluted diphtheria plus acellular pertussis. Tdap dose is given at 6 years as a proportion of average population 6-9 years. Do not administer Tdap for children who are younger than 6 years of age
useAndContext: Monitors protection of children against tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis including vaccinations done at schools
inclusions:
INCLUDE doses given during catch-up campaigns to children between 6 and 9 years

INCLUDE doses given during ‘mopping-up’ campaign 

INCLUDE Tdap dose at 6 years given at schools as part of school health services
exclusions:
EXCLUDE doses given during mopping –up campaigns conducted as part of mass campaign

EXCLUDE doses given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign

EXCLUDE children younger than 6 years
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register,  School Health Register, Hospital paediatric registers

name: Cataract surgery - total
definition: Number of eyes on which cataract surgery was performed
definitionExtended: Count each eye as cataract surgery performed. Cataract is opacity of the normally transparent lens
useAndContext: Monitors access to cataract surgery
inclusions: INCLUDE surgery with and without intraocular lens implants performed on clients of all ages
exclusions: None

name: Spectacles issued to child- total
definition: Number of spectacles issued to clients aged 7-18 years of age
definitionExtended: This should include all new spectacles issued to children including a new pair every 2 years. However, this should exclude spectacles re-issued due to the original pair not working for the patient. These data must be collected by a facility that orders spectacles for clients
useAndContext: Monitors access to eye care services
inclusions: INCLUDE all children aged 7-18 years who receive spectacles (both ready made and custom made spectacles) at public health facilities
exclusions: EXCLUDE spectacles re ordered due to wrong script or not working as expected.
collectedBy:
Eye clinic optometrists
Eye clinic ophthalmic nurses
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register;
Tick Register OPD

name: Spectacles required by child - total
definition: Spectacles (ordered) required for clients age 7-18 years of age
definitionExtended: This should exclude re-orders based on the fault of the lab making spectacles.
useAndContext: Monitors access to eye care services
inclusions: INCLUDE all spectacles ordered i.e. ready made and custom made spectacles for children aged 7-18 years.
exclusions: EXCLUDE re-ordered spectacles due to 1st pair not working for the client
collectedBy:
Eye clinic optometrists
Eye clinic ophthalmic nurses

name: Spectacles required by an adult - total
definition: Spectacles (ordered) required for clients aged 19 years and above
definitionExtended: This should exclude re-orders based on the fault of the lab making spectacles.
useAndContext: Monitors access to eye care services
inclusions: INCLUDE all spectacles ordered i.e. ready made and custom made spectacles for adults 19 years and above.
exclusions: EXCLUDE re-ordered spectacles due to 1st pair not working for the client

Eye clinic optometrists
Eye clinic ophthalmic nurses

name: Spectacles issued to an adult - total
definition: Number of spectacles issued to clients aged 19 years and older
definitionExtended: This should include all new spectacles issued to adults including a new pair every 2 years. However, this should exclude spectacles re-issued due to the original pair not working for the patient. These data must be collected by a facility that orders spectacles for clients
useAndContext: Monitors access to eye care services
inclusions: INCLUDE all adults 19 years and older who receive spectacles (both ready made and custom made spectacles) at public health facilities
exclusions: EXCLUDE spectacles re ordered due to wrong script or not working as expected.
collectedBy:
Eye clinic optometrists
Eye clinic ophthalmic nurses
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register;
Tick Register OPD

name: CD4 done on newly diagnosed HIV client
definition: CD4 test done on newly diagnosed HIV client
definitionExtended: Count only the first CD4 test done on newly diagnosed HIV client
useAndContext: This data element refers only to CD4 tests done on newly diagnosed HIV positive clients in the facility to monitor linkage to care
inclusions: None
exclusions: None
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register or TIER.Net

name: Female condoms distributed
definition: Female condoms distributed from a primary distribution site to health facilities or points in the community (e.g. campaigns, non-traditional outlets, etc.)
definitionExtended: Monitors distribution of female condoms for prevention of HIV and other STIs, and for contraceptive purposes. In some cases the primary distribution site might be at a hospital. The designated primary distribution points will be registered as separate "facilities" in the DHIS
useAndContext:
Monitors distribution of female condoms for prevention of HIV and other STIs, and for contraceptive purposes.
Primary distribution sites (PDS) must report to sub-districts on a monthly basis on how many female condoms were distributed to the sub-district in the reporting month
inclusions: INCLUDE ONLY female condoms distributed by the designated primary distribution site at district level
exclusions: EXCLUDE female condoms distributed by health facilities. Female condoms at health facilities to be monitored using clinical records or BIN card

name: All HIV positive clients on ART, initiated on TPT
definition: Number of HIV-positive clients currently on antiretroviral therapy (ART) who were newly initiated on tuberculosis preventive therapy (TPT) within a specified reporting period
definitionExtended: This data element represents the total count of HIV-positive individuals, who are actively receiving ART, who started a course of TPT (tuberculosis preventive therapy) for the first time during the defined reporting period. This excludes clients who may have been on TPT previously
useAndContext: This data element tracks the implementation of TB preventive therapy among HIV-positive individuals on ART, a crucial component of integrated HIV and TB care. It helps monitor the progress towards TB prevention goals and identify areas where TPT initiation needs to be strengthened. It is an important indicator for program monitoring and evaluation at the facility, provincial, national and international level. It informs resource allocation and strategy development for both TB and HIV services
inclusions:
INCLUDE Clients with a confirmed HIV-positive diagnosis

INCLUDE Clients currently receiving antiretroviral therapy (ART)

INCLUDE Clients who initiated TPT for the first time during the specified reporting period

NB: All TPT regimens are included (e.g. isoniazid, rifapentine) according to national guidelines
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Clients with an HIV-negative test result

EXCLUDE Clients who are HIV-positive but NOT currently receiving ART

EXCLUDE Clients who have initiated TPT prior to the defined reporting period

EXCLUDE Clients who have completed a course of TPT previously and are not re-initiating

EXCLUDE Clients prescribed TPT for active TB treatment
frequency: Data collected daily and collated monthly
collectedBy:
Clinicians (prescribing and documenting TPT)

Data Capturers/Program Personnel (entering data into the Tier.NET)
tools: ART Clinical stationery which then is captured in TIER.NET (HIV Monthly report)

name: All HIV positive clients on ART eligible for TPT
definition: All HIV positive clients on ART eligible for TPT
definitionExtended: Includes all HIV positive clients who are on Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) and are eligible for TB Preventive Therapy (TPT)
useAndContext: This data element monitors the eligibility of HIV positive clients on ART for TB Preventive Therapy (TPT). It includes all HIV positive clients who are currently on ART and have been determined to be eligible for TPT. Clients who are HIV negative or who are HIV positive but not yet on ART are excluded from this data element
exclusions:
EXCLUDE HIV positive clients not on ART 

EXCLUDE Individuals who are HIV-negative

EXCLUDE Individuals who are HIV-positive but not currently on ART

EXCLUDE Individuals who are HIV-positive and on ART but have been diagnosed with active TB disease

EXCLUDE Individuals for whom TPT is contraindicated (e.g., due to drug allergies) based on the latest national guidelines
frequency: Data collected daily and collated monthly
collectedBy:
Clinician (or other trained healthcare provider) who conducts the TPT eligibility assessment and documents the clinical notes
Data capturer (person responsible for transcribing clinical notes into the Tier.NET)
tools: ART Clinical stationery which then is captured in Tier.NET (HIV Monthly report)

name: HIV positive screened for TB
definition: Number of HIV-positive clients screened for TB during a defined period
definitionExtended: This data element captures the count of HIV-positive individuals who have undergone TB screening during any healthcare visit. Screening involves asking specific questions and/or performing a physical examination to identify individuals who may be at risk for active TB or have presumptive TB. This data element is critical for monitoring adherence to clinical guidelines and ensuring timely identification of TB in people living with HIV (PLHIV)
useAndContext:
This data element is used to track the implementation of national guidelines (e.g., ART (2023) and TB (2014) Clinical Guidelines) that mandate TB screening for all PLHIV at every clinical encounter. TB is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality among PLHIV, making routine screening essential for early detection and prompt initiation of preventative or treatment protocols. Data from this element is used to:
1.Assess the coverage of TB screening in PLHIV
2.Identify gaps in service delivery and areas for improvement
3. Monitor the performance of facilities in adhering to clinical guidelines
4.Inform program planning and resource allocation
5.Track progress toward national and international targets for TB prevention and control in PLHIV
inclusions:
INCLUDE All clients, regardless of age or gender, who:

Have a confirmed positive HIV test result
Have undergone a TB screening assessment
Antenatal clients who tested positive for HIV, meeting the above criteria
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Clients with a negative HIV test result 
                                                                                                                         
EXCLUDE HIV-positive clients who are not screened for TB during a clinical encounter
frequency: Collect daily and compile monthly. Data should be reviewed weekly for anomalies.
tools: HTS Register (HIV Testing Services) or HTS module in TIER.Net

name: HIV positive 15-24 years female (excl ANC)
definition: HIV test positive females in the 15-24 year age group (excluding antenatal)
definitionExtended: Includes only the first positive HIV test  within the reporting period
useAndContext: Monitors the impact of the HIV pandemic to assist in planning for effective strategies in combating HIV and AIDS
inclusions: INCLUDE First-time positive HIV test results for females aged 15-24 outside of ANC
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Antenatal clients

EXCLUDE repeat tests on the same client to confirm diagnosis

definition: HIV test positive males in the 15-24 year age group
definitionExtended: Includes only the first positive HIV test within the reporting period.

inclusions: INCLUDE First-time positive HIV test results for males aged 15-24
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Antenatal clients

EXCLUDE repeat tests on the same client to confirm diagnosis

exclusions: EXCLUDE repeat tests on the same client to confirm diagnosis

definitionExtended: Includes only the first positive HIV test within the reporting period.
useAndContext: Monitors the impact of the HIV pandemic on children to assist in planning for effective strategies in combating HIV and AIDS
inclusions: INCLUDE First-time positive HIV test results for children aged 5-14 outside of ANC

name: HIV positive known but NOT on ART
definition: Clients with known HIV positive status but not on ART. In the absence of documented proof, HIV testing should be done as required by guidelines and a CD4 count test must be done.
definitionExtended: Patients who were never initiated on ART
useAndContext: Monitors HIV clients on ART
inclusions: INCLUDE Individuals with documented HIV-positive status, confirmed by testing if necessary
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Individuals currently receiving ART

EXCLUDE Individuals whose HIV status is unknown or undocumented.

name: HIV test 15-24 years female (excl ANC)
definition: HIV rapid tests done in females in the 15-24 year age group
definitionExtended: Includes all rapid HIV tests performed within the specified criteria, regardless of the result.
useAndContext: Monitors HIV counselling and testing services among youth 15 to 24 years
inclusions: None

EXCLUDE Antenatal clients

name: Male condoms distributed
definition: Male condoms distributed from a primary distribution site to health facilities or points in the community (e.g. campaigns, non-traditional outlets, etc.)
definitionExtended: Monitors distribution of male condoms for prevention of HIV and other STIs, and for contraceptive purposes. Note that research indicates only around 60% of distributed condoms are used for the intended purpose. In some cases the primary distribution site might be at a hospital. The designated primary distribution points will be registered as separate "facilities" in the DHIS
useAndContext:
Monitors distribution of male condoms for prevention of HIV and other STIs, and for contraceptive purposes.
Primary distribution sites (PDS) must report to sub-districts on a monthly basis on how many male condoms were distributed to the sub-district in the reporting month
inclusions: INCLUDE ONLY male condoms distributed by the designated primary distribution site at district level
exclusions: EXCLUDE male condoms distributed by health facilities. Male condoms at health facilities to be monitored using clinical records or BIN card

name: Medical male circumcision 10-14 years
definition: Males 10 to 14 years who are circumcised under medical supervision at healthcare facilities including mobile facilities
definitionExtended:
Includes circumcisions performed using surgical methods (e.g., dorsal slit, forceps-guided).
Medical supervision implies a trained healthcare professional (Physician, clinical officer or nurse) performing or directly overseeing the procedure, adhering to national MMC guidelines and infection prevention standards.
The age is determined by the documented age at the time of the procedure. If documented age is not available, an estimate is made based on the best available evidence and documented
useAndContext: Monitors medical male circumcisions 10-14 years performed
inclusions: INCLUDE medical male circumcisions done by private practitioners and NGOs
exclusions: EXCLUDE male circumcision performed in the traditional sector
collectionPoints: Facilities where male circumcisions are performed

name: Medical male circumcision 15 years and older
definition: Males 15 years and older who are circumcised under medical supervision at healthcare facilities including mobile facilities
definitionExtended: Record all males who are circumcised under medical supervision
useAndContext: Monitors medical male circumcisions 15 years and older performed
inclusions: INCLUDE medical male circumcisions done by private practitioners and NGOs
exclusions: EXCLUDE Male circumcision performed in the traditional sector
collectionPoints: Facilities where male circumcisions are performed

name: New sexual offence case seen at health facility
definition: Sexual offence encompass a range of acts to which consent has not been given and is usually accompanied by emotional or physical violence. Male and female sexual  offence  cases
definitionExtended: This data element captures the count of individuals who have experienced a recent incident of sexual offence (including but not limited to rape, sexual violence, sexual harassment, or sexual coercion) and are presenting at the health facility for the first time for assessment, medical treatment, or support related to this incident. This includes cases where an individual reports they did not consent to sexual activity and is seeking care. This include new case, reported unwanted sexual contact, reported sexual violence, sexual coercion, reported sexual sexual exploitation and all the genders
useAndContext: This data element helps to monitor the incidence of sexual offence and access to care, identify trends over time, inform resource allocation for care and support services, and evaluate the effectiveness of prevention and response programs. This data can indirectly support HIV programming with regard to Post Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) provision
tools:
Tick Register OPD
PHC Tick register

name: New sexual offence case HIV negative issued with Post Exposure Prophylaxis
definition: This data element captures the number of new individuals presenting for care following a sexual offence, testing HIV negative, and subsequently initiated on Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP). This includes individuals of all ages and genders
definitionExtended: This data element monitors the provision of post-exposure prophylaxis to sexual offence victims who have tested negative for HIV. This information can help improve the management and treatment of sexual offence cases and prevent the spread of HIV
useAndContext: This data element can help inform policies and interventions related to sexual offence prevention, response, and treatment. It can also help track the effectiveness of PEP administration and identify potential areas for improvement
inclusions:
INCLUDE:
Cases of sexual offence reported to healthcare facilities

Victims tested HIV negative at the time of reporting

PEP administration to the victim after the offence
exclusions:
EXCLUDE:
Consensual sexual contact, including cases where a condom breaks during sex

Occupational Exposure: Cases of occupational exposures (e.g., needle-stick injuries in healthcare workers)

Follow-Up Cases: Individuals returning for follow-up care related to a previously reported sexual assault within the reporting period; such cases would be a separate data element

Historical cases: Cases relating to sexual assault incidents that occurred outside of the reporting period, unless they are new presentations within the reporting period

Cases reported after 72 hours

name: HIV test 18-24 months
definition: Number of children aged 18-24 months who receive an HIV antibody test (rapid or standard)
definitionExtended: This data element tracks the number of children aged 18-24 months undergoing HIV antibody testing. This is critical for monitoring HIV transmission rates and ensuring early identification and linkage to care and treatment for HIV-positive children. The data informs program planning and quality improvement efforts related to pediatric HIV services
useAndContext: This data element is used to monitor the implementation of HIV testing policies and guidelines for infants and young children. It helps healthcare providers track the number of children who receive an HIV test between 18-24 months of age and identify any gaps or barriers to accessing HIV testing services
inclusions: INCLUDE All  HIV test results from rapid antibody tests conducted between 18-24 months of age
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Confirmatory HIV test results

 EXCLUDE HIV test results from children under 18 months or over 24 months of age
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; HTS Register (HIV Testing Services) or HCT module in TIER.Net

name: HIV test positive 18-24 months
definition: Children who tested HIV  positive using  rapid  antibody test at 18-24 months
definitionExtended: This refers to the initial positive HIV test result obtained via a rapid antibody test performed on a child between 18 and 24 months of age. The test must be documented and performed according to established national HIV testing algorithms
useAndContext: Monitors HIV transmission around 18 months
inclusions: INCLUDE all positive HIV tests done between  18-24 months
exclusions: EXCLUDE confirmatory tests
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; HTS Register (HIV Testing Services) or HCT module in TIER.Net

name: Total remaining on PrEP
definition:
Total remaining on PrEP is the sum of:
-All clients with a continuing on PrEP outcome.
-Clients without an outcome  (TFO, RIP, LTF, Client discontinued, Clinician discontinued, pregnancy, HIV Positive)+ start PrEP for the reporting month
definitionExtended: This is a point-in-time measure. It represents the active PrEP users at the end of the reporting period. "Without a documented outcome" refers to clients who started PrEP in the current or previous periods and have not yet been assigned an outcome (e.g., transferred out, stopped PrEP) by the end of the current report period. This value is calculated at the end of the specified month (or reporting period)
useAndContext: For program monitoring and GAM reporting. Tracks PrEP coverage and retention.
inclusions:
INCLUDE Clients with a "continuing on PrEP" outcome at the end of the reporting period

INCLUDE Clients without a documented outcome (TFO, RIP, LTF, Client Discontinued, Clinician Discontinued, Pregnancy, HIV Positive) at the end of the reporting period AND started PrEP in the current or previous reporting period.
exclusions: EXCLUDE clients who have an outcome in the specified month or months previous
tools: PrEP clinical record captured on TIER.NET

name: Person exposed to HIV who tested HIV negative and was issued with Post Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP)
definition: All male and female  of all age groups issued with PEP
definitionExtended: PEP reduces the probability of HIV infection after exposure to potentially HIV infected blood or body fluids. For maximum effectiveness, PEP should be provided within 72 hours after exposure
useAndContext: For program monitoring and GAM reporting
inclusions:
INCLUDE PEP issued to a client who was potentially exposed to HIV

INCLUDE Male and female occupational and non-occupational exposure
exclusions: EXCLUDE Persons that were sexually assaulted

name: HIV test 25-59 months
definition: HIV rapid tests done in children from 25 – 59 months
definitionExtended: The HIV Testing in Children (25-59 months) data element measures the number of HIV rapid tests performed in children aged between 25 and 59 months. This information helps monitor the provision of HIV counselling and testing services for children in accordance with the Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMCI) guidelines
useAndContext: This data element is essential for monitoring the implementation of HIV testing services for older infants and young children, as recommended by IMCI guidelines. It helps assess the reach of HIV testing programs targeting this specific age group, identify areas of underperformance, and informs resource allocation for HIV prevention programs. It also contributes to tracking potential delays in diagnosis and treatment initiation
inclusions:
INCLUDE All HIV rapid antibody tests performed on children aged 25 completed months up to, and inclusive of, 59 completed months

INCLUDE tests performed for any reason (e.g., routine testing, suspected exposure, specific clinical presentation)

INCLUDE instances where repeat testing occurs within this timeframe with the aim of a new result
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Children who have been previously confirmed as HIV-positive and are currently on antiretroviral therapy (ART)

EXCLUDE HIV tests conducted on children under 25 completed months of age

EXCLUDE HIV tests conducted on children over 59 completed months of age

EXCLUDE Any HIV tests that are not rapid antibody tests

EXCLUDE Any confirmatory testing which follows from a positive result of an antibody test
collectionPoints: All healthcare facilities, community HTS services

name: HIV test positive 25-59 months
definition: HIV test positive in the 25-59 months age group
definitionExtended: This data element captures instances of confirmed HIV positivity among children within the age range of 25 to 59 months. A 'positive' result refers to a laboratory-confirmed diagnosis of HIV through age-appropriate testing methods, such as antibody testing. This element will help create a clearer picture of HIV's impact on young children, guiding public health responses tailored to this vulnerable population.
useAndContext: This data element is used to monitor the impact of the HIV pandemic on children aged 25-59 months to assist in planning for effective strategies in combating HIV and AIDS. This information can help track the prevalence of HIV in this age group and inform prevention and treatment efforts.
inclusions:
INCLUDE Children aged 25-59 months who have tested positive for HIV using an age-appropriate test (antibody test)

 INCLUDE Both new and repeat testers are included, as long as they meet the age requirement and test positive
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Repeat tests on the same client solely to confirm diagnosis (only the first positive test result should be counted) 
EXCLUDE Children aged <25 months or >59 months who test positive for HIV
collectionPoints: All healthcare facilities, community HTS services

name: Client Screened using HIVSS (12 years and above)
definition: Individuals aged 12 years and above who utilize HIV self-testing (HIVST) for HIV screening.
definitionExtended: This data element captures all individuals aged 12 years and above, including those from populations with specific access barriers (those with aversion to traditional testing settings, hard-to-reach individuals, key populations, and those with fear of needles), who undergo HIV screening using HIV self-testing (HIVST). This testing may be conducted in healthcare facilities, community settings, workplaces, or during outreach initiatives. The data aims to monitor the reach and uptake of HIVST, particularly among those not routinely accessing traditional HIV testing services, ultimately contributing to earlier identification of HIV and linkage to care and treatment.
useAndContext: Evidence suggests that HIVST has the potential to expand access to HIV testing, particularly among populations not routinely accessing facility-based services. HIVST offers a convenient, confidential, and unsupervised testing option. Data from this indicator is used to monitor the reach of testing services, identify populations that may require additional support, and evaluate the contribution of HIVST in increasing case finding and linkage to care.
inclusions:
INCLUDE Individuals aged 12 years and above utilizing HIVST for screening
INCLUDE Individuals from populations with barriers to accessing traditional testing (averse to traditional testing settings, hard-to-reach individuals, key populations, and those with fear of needles)
INCLUDE HIVST provided and used in healthcare facilities, community settings, workplaces, and during outreach initiatives
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Individuals under the age of 12 years
EXCLUDE Individuals unable to consent due to mental instability
EXCLUDE Individuals currently on antiretroviral therapy (ART), post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), or pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)
EXCLUDE Pregnant women
collectionPoints: Healthcare facilities, communities, prisons, workplace and health campaigns

name: Patients on ART enrolled in repeat prescription collection strategies (DMOC)of Adherence clubs
definition: All patients receiving ART repeat prescription through Adherence club collection strategy
definitionExtended: Stable ART patients, moved into a Differentiated Model of Care (DMOC), specifically Adherence Clubs, for repeat ART prescription collection. These patients must also meet the following stability criteria: 1) Viral Load (VL) < 50 copies/ml, 2) HbA1c < 8%, 3) Two consecutive Blood Pressure (BP) readings < 140/90. Stability is reviewed every 6 months during a scheduled clinic appointment.
useAndContext: This indicator measures the reach of Adherence Club DMOC within the facility. Tracking these numbers helps monitor the success of differentiated care models and inform decisions about expanding Adherence Clubs as part of the overall ART service delivery model.
inclusions:
INCLUDE All stable ART patients, meeting the specified stability criteria, receiving ART through Adherence clubs
INCLUDE Stable ART patients also receiving chronic treatment for hypertension, diabetes mellitus, or TB treatment, and receiving ART through Adherence clubs
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Patients not on ART
EXCLUDE Patients receiving ART through Facility or other External pick-up points
EXCLUDE Patients not meeting the specified stability criteria, even if enrolled in an adherence club for other reasons
collectedBy:
Clinician responsible for patient stability assessment, DMOC placement & writing notes in the clinical stationery.
Data capturer responsible for documenting data  from clinical stationery in to Tier.NET system.

name: Patients on ART enrolled in repeat prescription collection strategies (DMOC) of Facility pick Up
definition: All patients receiving ART repeat prescription through Facility Pick up collection strategy
definitionExtended: Stable ART patients, moved into a Differentiated Model of Care (DMOC), specifically Facility Pick-Up Point, for repeat ART prescription collection. These patients must also meet the following stability criteria: 1) Viral Load (VL) < 50 copies/ml, 2) HbA1c < 8%, 3) Two consecutive Blood Pressure (BP) readings < 140/90. Stability is reviewed every 6 months during a scheduled clinic appointment.
useAndContext: This indicator measures the reach of Facility Pick-Up point within the facility. Tracking these numbers helps monitor the success of differentiated care models and inform decisions about expanding facility pick up point as part of the overall ART service delivery model.
inclusions:
INCLUDE All stable ART patients, meeting the specified stability criteria, receiving ART through Facility Pick-Up point
INCLUDE Stable patients also receiving chronic treatment for hypertension, diabetes mellitus, or TB treatment, and receiving ART through Facility Pick-Up point.
exclusions: EXCLUDE Chronic patients without ART
collectedBy:
Clinician responsible for patient stability assessment, DMOC placement & writing notes in the clinical stationery
Data capturer responsible for documenting data  from clinical stationery in to Tier.NET system.

name: Accident and Emergency (Casualty) and Trauma unit headcount - Emergency
shortname: Accident and Emergency (Casualty) and Trauma unit headcount - Emergency
definition: All clients attending the Accident and Emergency (Casualty) and Trauma unit in a facility with conditions requiring emergency treatment only
definitionExtended: A medical emergency is an injury or illness that is acute and poses an immediate risk to a person`s life or long term health. Do not count non-emergency cases(cold cases) that attend the Casualty department after hours when OPD is closed. Non-emergency cases should be counted as part of the Casualty-non-emergency data elements (new cases with or without referral letters or follow-up cases). Typical examples of emergency are strokes, cardiac arrests, drowning, poisoning, clients in shock, children with high fever, asthma attacks, assaults, gunshots, motor vehicle accidents, rape cases and others. Emergency treatment is given to stabilize the client, where after the patient will usually be admitted for further treatment. A patient in the Accident and emergency unit who requires inpatient care, as determined and instructed by the clinician (i.e. Clinician instruction to admit at current or referral hospital), while waiting for a bed in the admission ward or a bed in the referral hospital should be counted as an emergency visit AND  registered and counted as an inpatient (against the appropriate admissions discipline/specialty), irrespective of where the patient is accommodated and whether they are accommodated in a bed or not, even i.e. if the patient is accommodated at Accident and Emergency unit in a bed, chair, trolley, floor etc. All non-emergency (cold cases) seen in Casualty unit should not be counted.
useAndContext: Weighted data element as proxy for estimating resources for all types of patients in terms of inpatient days
inclusions: INCLUDE only emergency cases
exclusions: EXCLUDE non-emergency cases
tools: Accident and Emergency unit (Casualty) and Trauma unit register

name: Accident and Emergency (Casualty) unit headcount - non-Emergency
shortname: Accident and Emergency (Casualty) unit headcount - non-Emergency
definition: All clients attending the Accident and Emergency unit (Casualty) in a facility with conditions requiring non-emergency  treatment
definitionExtended: A medical emergency is an injury or illness that is acute and poses an immediate risk to a person's life or long term health. Count non-emergency cases that attend the Casualty department after hours when OPD is closed. Non-emergency cases should be counted as part pf the Casualty-non-emergency data elements (all the OPD cases without referral letter. All assessments of pregnant women to determine progression of labour must be registered if patient presents at Casualty. All non-emergency (cold cases) seen in Casualty unit should be counted. All assessments of pregnant women to determine progression of labour must be registered if patient presents at Casualty .
useAndContext: Weighted data element as proxy for estimating resources for all types of patients in terms of inpatient days
inclusions: include all non-emergency (cold) cases. All assessments of pregnant women to determine progression of labour must be registered as a casualty unit if patient presents at Casualty .
exclusions: EXCLUDE emergency cases. Exclude assessments of pregnant women to determine progression of labour must not be registered at casualty unit if patient presents directly at Labour unit .
tools: Accident and Emergency unit (Casualty) and Trauma unit register

name: Day patient - Neonatal
definition: Day patient - Neonatal ICU + Day patient - Neonatal High Care + Day patient - Neonatal Standard Inpatient Care
definitionExtended: Day patient - Neonatal ICU + Day patient - Neonatal High Care + Day patient - Neonatal Standard Inpatient Care
useAndContext: To quantify the total neonatal day patients
inclusions: None
exclusions: None

name: Day patient - total
definition: The total count of inpatients admitted in hospitals and CHC/CDC and separated on the same calendar day.
definitionExtended: These patients do not occupy a bed at midnight.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.

name: Day patient - Gynaecology
definition: An Gynaecology inpatient admitted and separated on the same calendar day
definitionExtended: Gynaecology: Investigates and treats problems relating to the female urinary tract and reproductive organs. These patients do not occupy a bed at midnight. Record all day patients also under the relevant separation data element: `Inpatient discharges-all`, `Inpatient deaths-all`, or `Inpatient transferred out - all`. Count as a Gynaecology day patient regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupy, e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a day patient for the sub-category they were admitted for.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.

name: Day patient - Maternity
definition: A maternity inpatient admitted and separated on the same calendar day
definitionExtended: Maternity: Provides antenatal care, delivery of babies and care during childbirth, and postnatal support. These patients do not occupy a bed at midnight. Record all day patients also under the relevant separation data element: `Inpatient discharges-all`, `Inpatient deaths-all`, or `Inpatient transferred out - all`. Count as a Maternity day patient regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupy,  e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a day patient for the sub-category they were admitted for
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.

name: Day patient - Medicine
definition: A medicine inpatient admitted and separated on the same calendar day
definitionExtended: Medicine: The diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease excluding surgery. Day patient-Medicine includes TB. Count as a Medicine day patient regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupy, e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a day patient for the sub-category they were admitted for
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
exclusions:
EXCLUDE patients who were supposed to stay overnight, but left of their own accord;
EXCLUDE patients who do not require inpatient care but who are waiting for an ambulance for transport to a referral hospital

name: Dead on arrival
definition: A patient who is certified dead on arrival
definitionExtended: Patient who is certified dead on arrival at facility before any resuscitation is attempted. Count as a death on arrival if no intervention by facility health professionals
useAndContext: To facilitate registration of death with Home Affairs. Death registration assist in compiling accurate, complete, and timely vital statistics, which, along with population censuses, are central to estimating population size.
inclusions:
INCLUDE as death if patient died in transit by EMS; 
INCLUDE BBA DOA and neonatal deaths (infants aged 0-28 days) outside of the facility
exclusions: EXCLUDE death in Casualty and inpatient
collectionPoints: Accident and Emergency (Casualty) and Trauma unit
tools: Accident and Emergency unit (Casualty) and Trauma unit register

exclusions: None

name: Inpatient beds - ICU
definition: Inpatient beds - ICU is a subcategory of inpatient beds that are approved for use within the health facility. Hospitals should use their routine data to determine the number of beds needed for ICU patients. This is a semi-permanent data element that should only be revised on an annual basis if there's a change in the need for ICU beds.
definitionExtended: Intensive Care: is a special department in a hospital where seriously ill patients, that require close observation and monitoring, are cared for by specially trained staff that provides intensive treatment for patients requiring advanced respiratory support, support of two or more failing organ systems or treatment of life threatening infections. A bed is a unit of accommodation in a health facility. A bed is used for admitting patients. An admission is a patient who undergoes the hospital formal admission process for either a patient or a day patient because they require inpatient care that cannot be administered on an outpatient basis. A bed is used for an admitted client and not for a boarder (e.g. kangaroo mothers), a well-baby, a client undergoing a procedure (e.g. in theatre) or an outpatient undergoing procedures, examinations or resuscitation. Hospitals with an inpatient bed sub-category of ICU must also report inpatient days, day patients, inpatient discharges and inpatient transfers for the sub-category of ICU.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: Includes all disciplines of ICU
exclusions: EXCLUDE surgical tables, recovery trolleys, stretchers, chairs and recliners (e.g. as used for renal dialysis patients etc.)

name: Inpatient beds - Neonatal
definition: Inpatient beds-Neonatal ICU + Inpatient beds-Neonatal High Care + Inpatient beds-Neonatal Standard Inpatient Care
definitionExtended: Inpatient beds-Neonatal ICU + Inpatient beds-Neonatal High Care + Inpatient beds-Neonatal Standard Inpatient Care
useAndContext: To quantify the total neonatal beds
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE surgical tables, recovery trolleys, stretchers, chairs and recliners (e.g. as used for renal dialysis patients etc.)

name: Inpatient beds - Neonatal Standard Inpatient Care
definition: Inpatient beds - Standard sick neonate (NSIC)is a subcategory of inpatient beds that are approved for use within the health facility. The number of inpatient beds should include neonatal beds in Kangaroo Mother Care units. This includes admissions of neonates in Kangaroo Mother Care unit in nurseries, paediatric wards as well as postnatal wards where there are no neonatal units for sick neonates
definitionExtended: Hospitals should use their routine data to determine the number of beds needed for Neonatal sick inpatients. This is a semi-permanent data element that should only be revised on an annual basis if there is a change in the need for Neonatal sick inpatient beds. This is a subset of Inpatient Beds - Paediatrics
useAndContext: Hospitals with an inpatient bed sub-category of Standard Sick Neonatal care must also report inpatient days, day patients, inpatient discharges and inpatient transfers for the sub-category of Standard Sick Neonatal
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE delivery beds, surgical tables, recovery trolleys, cots for normal neonates (well baby cots), stretchers, chairs and recliners (e.g. as used for renal dialysis patients etc.); EXCLUDE: High Care and ICU neonatal beds

name: Inpatient beds approved - total
definition: Number of approved inpatient beds for the health facility. The number of approved beds is a semi permanent data element. Any increase or decrease must be motivated and can only be done through the office of the HOD and National Department of Health should be informed when such changes occur.
definitionExtended: A bed is a unit of accommodation in a health facility. A bed is used for admitting patients. An admission is a patient who undergoes the hospital formal admission process for either a patient or a day patient because they require inpatient care that cannot be administered on an outpatient basis. A bed is used for an admitted client and not for a boarder (e.g. kangaroo mothers), a well-baby, a client undergoing a procedure (e.g. in theatre) or an outpatient undergoing procedures, examinations or resuscitation.

exclusions: EXCLUDE delivery beds, surgical tables, recovery trolleys, cots for normal neonates (well baby cots), stretchers, chairs and recliners (e.g. as used for renal dialysis patients etc.)

A bed is a unit of accommodation in a health facility. A bed is used for admitting patients. An admission is a patient who undergoes the hospital formal admission process for either a patient or a day patient because they require inpatient care that cannot be administered on an outpatient basis. A bed is used for an admitted client and not for a boarder (e.g. kangaroo mothers), a well-baby, a client undergoing a procedure (e.g. in theatre) or an outpatient undergoing procedures, examinations or resuscitation. Hospitals with an inpatient bed sub-category of Surgery must also report inpatient days, day patients, inpatient discharges and inpatient transfers for the sub-category of Surgery.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE surgical tables, recovery trolleys, stretchers, chairs and recliners (e.g. as used for renal dialysis patients etc.)

definitionExtended: Inpatient days-Neonatal ICU + Inpatient days-Neonatal High Care + Inpatient days-Neonatal Standard Inpatient Care
useAndContext: To quantify the total neonatal discharges

exclusions: None

name: Inpatient days - total

name: Inpatient days - Gynaecology
definition: Total number of days Gynaecology inpatients spent in the institution during the period. A day is the count of all patients occupying a bed at midnight
definitionExtended:
Gynaecology: Investigates and treats problems relating to the female urinary tract and reproductive organs. Inpatient days should exclusively be based on the midnight census, not on admissions or other administrative procedures. The following rules apply:
A patient discharged on the day following the date of admission has a stay of 1 (one) patient day. A patient discharged 2 (two) days after the date of admission (e.g. admitted on Tuesday and discharged on Thursday) has a stay of 2 (two) patient days. Count as a Gynaecology inpatient regardless of the sub-category of bed the inpatient occupy-for e.g. if there is an overflow of one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a inpatient for the sub-category they were admitted for.
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.

name: Inpatient discharges - total
definition: An inpatient discharge is a patient admitted to a ward that completes an inpatient stay and is discharged to their usual residence including home, family, correctional centre, hostel etc.-including the discharge of a patient on the same day of admission. The total is specialities plus all others that do not appear on the identified specialities.
definitionExtended:
Avoid using admissions as a proxy for discharges, except as a last resort. Note that while there might seem to be a fine line between sub-acute facilities, frail care centres, and old age homes, the difference lies in the term `discharged to their usual residence`. 
If the patient is sent to another health facility other than his/her usual residence-presumably for a limited time before the client will continue to his/her usual residence-it is regarded as a transfer out. 
If an inpatient at one facility attends a second facility as an outpatient and the patient is then admitted after the OPD visit, the referring facility must not discharge or suspend the patient until the second facility informed the referring facility to discharge the patient from their facility.
Weekend leave: Facilities should discharge clients on weekend leave except H1 clients
useAndContext: Monitors effectiveness and efficiency of inpatient management.
