name: OPD headcount follow-up
definition: Client attending a general or specialist Outpatient clinic for follow-up care
definitionExtended:
This would include visits to Service Groups like Physiotherapist, Dietician, X-rays, etc., as well as previous ward attendees returning to the hospital for a check-up. Clients can be seen in the OPD section of the hospital. Count each client only once for the day irrespective of the number of services provided. All assessments of pregnant women to determine progression of labour must be registered as an OPD visit. The assessment may take place in the emergency centre or in a specific area and the facility should keep a register of the visits.
Outpatients transported by ambulance to another facility and requiring emergency attention at a facility en route must be recorded as an emergency visit en route.
An inpatient at one facility attends a second facility as an outpatient, the second facility must record the attendance as an OPD visit
useAndContext: Weighted data element as proxy for estimating resources for all types of patients in terms of inpatient days
inclusions:
INCLUDE clients for follow-up visits at general and specialist Outpatient clinic

INCLUDE visits to Service Groups like Physiotherapist, Dietician, X-rays, etc., as well as previous inpatients returning to the hospital 

INCLUDE telehealth visits conducted by a health care worker

INCLUDE all clinical visits conducted by a healthcare worker including specialists, doctors, nurses (all ranks), counsellors, allied health professionals, pharmacist, radiologist etc
exclusions:
EXCLUDE inpatients seen at an outpatient clinic

EXCLUDE cases where a private doctor examines a pregnant woman at his/her private rooms and then refers the client for admission as his/her private patient
This should only be registered as an admission and not as an OPD visit as well.

name: OPD headcount not referred new
definition: New clients attending a general or specialist Outpatient clinic WITHOUT a referral letter from a PHC facility or a doctor
definitionExtended: Clients must be seen in the OPD section of the hospital. Count each client only once for the day irrespective of the number of services provided. If there are arrangements in a facility to provide an outpatient service in a ward due to shortage of space, the facility should keep a register of the visits. Clients/patients seen in the OPD and then admitted should be recorded as an OPD visit as well as an admission. Outpatients transported by ambulance to another facility and requiring emergency attention at a facility en route must be recorded as an emergency visit en route
useAndContext: Monitors utilisation trends of clients by-passing PHC facilities and the effect of PHC re-engineering on OPD utilisation.
inclusions:
INCLUDE telehealth visits conducted by a health care worker

INCLUDE All clinical visits conducted by a healthcare worker including specialists, doctors, nurses (all ranks), counsellors, allied health professionals, pharmacist, radiologist etc
exclusions:
EXCLUDE inpatients of the same hospital seen at an outpatient clinic

EXCLUDE new OPD clients with referral letters and those for follow-up visits

name: OPD headcount referred new
definition: New client attending a general or specialist Outpatient clinic with a referral letter from a PHC facility or a doctor
definitionExtended:
Clients can be seen in the OPD section of the hospital. Count each client only once for the day irrespective of the number of services provided. All assessments of pregnant women to determine progression of labour must be registered as an OPD visit. The assessment may take place in the emergency centre or in a specific area and the facility should keep a register of the visits.
Outpatients transported by ambulance to another facility and requiring emergency attention at a facility en route must be recorded as an emergency visit en route.
An inpatient at one facility attends a second facility as an outpatient, the second facility must record the attendance as an OPD visit
useAndContext: Monitors utilisation trends of clients by-passing PHC facilities and the effect of PHC re-engineering on OPD utilisation.
inclusions:
INCLUDE telehealth visits conducted by a health care worker

INCLUDE All clinical visits conducted by a healthcare worker including specialists, doctors, nurses (all ranks), counsellors, allied health professionals, pharmacist, radiologist etc.
exclusions:
EXCLUDE inpatients of the same hospital seen at an outpatient clinic

EXCLUDE new OPD clients with referral letters and those for follow-up visits

EXCLUDE cases where a private doctor examines a pregnant woman at his/her private rooms and then refers the patient for admission as his/her private client.
This should only be registered as an admission and not as an OPD visit as well.

name: Inpatient death - Maternity
definition: An inpatient death maternity is a death recorded against an admitted maternity inpatient, including the death of a patient admitted earlier on the same day
definitionExtended: Maternity: Provides antenatal care, delivery of babies and care during childbirth, and postnatal support. Count any death of an inpatient, even if the cause of death does not directly relate to the cause of admission or the specialty of the ward. For instance, a death due to an accident or an act of violence must be counted
useAndContext: Count as a Maternity Inpatient death regardless of the sub-category of bed the patient occupy when the death occurs - for e.g. when there is an overflow of  one sub-category patients into another sub-category beds, the patient must be counted as a inpatient death for the sub-category they were admitted for.

name: Assault case - new

definitionExtended: It includes all cases where there was an act of inflicting physical harm upon a person which might lead to injury and emotional trauma
useAndContext: To quantify the total assault cases
inclusions: None
exclusions: Excludes assault caused by/as a result of sexual assault , gunshots, bite, fall, burn, motor vehicle accident and pedestrian vehicle accident.
tools: Accident and Emergency (Casualty) and Trauma unit Register

name: Burns - new
definition: A client presenting with physical or emotional trauma related to burns
definitionExtended: It includes all injuries caused by exposure to heat or flame.
useAndContext: To quantify the total burns cases
inclusions: None
exclusions: None
tools: Accident and Emergency (Casualty) and Trauma unit Register

name: Gunshots - new
definition: A client presenting with physical or emotional trauma related to gunshots
definitionExtended: It includes all cases where clients present to the facility with injuries due to  being shot by a gun
useAndContext: To quantify the total gunshot cases

exclusions: None

definitionExtended: It includes all cases where clients present to the facility with injuries due to a motor vehicle accident, collision or crash between two or more vehicles or a single vehicle that overturned.
useAndContext: To quantify the total motor vehicle accidents
inclusions: None
exclusions: None

definitionExtended: It includes all cases where clients present to the facility with injuries relating to an accident in which they were stricken by a vehicle
useAndContext: To quantify the total pedestrian  vehicle accidents
inclusions: None
exclusions: None
tools: Accident and Emergency (Casualty)and Trauma unit Register

definitionExtended: It includes all cases where clients present to the facility with injuries relating to human, dog and snake bites

exclusions: None

definitionExtended: It includes all cases where clients present to the facility with injuries relating to falls which can make it hard for a person to get around, do everyday activities or live on their own
useAndContext: To quantify the total falls
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE falls related to sport
tools: Accident and Emergency (Casualty)and Trauma unit Register

name: Sports related trauma - new
definition: A client presenting with physical or emotional trauma related to sports
definitionExtended: It includes all cases where there is an act of inflicting physical harm upon a person relating to sports which might lead to injury and emotional trauma
useAndContext: To quantify the total sports related trauma
inclusions: None
exclusions: None
tools: Accident and Emergency (Casualty)and Trauma unit Register

name: PHC client seen by doctor (full time/sessional)
definition: A PHC client consulted and or treated by a doctor employed full time/sessional in the public sector to render general clinical services
definitionExtended: This data element should be collected in all PHC facilities with full time / sessional doctors. Clients might originally be seen by a professional nurse for a PHC service or may be seen directly by the doctor; Each client is counted every time they are seen by a doctor, even if a client is seen by more than one doctor per day or client visit facility more than once per day and seen by a doctor; ONLY clients seen for preventive, promotive and curative must be counted
useAndContext: Monitoring of services rendered by public full time / sessional doctors to consult PHC clients in public health facilities in accordance with the NHI objectives to increase doctor coverage
inclusions: INCLUDE patient seen for renewal of prescriptions
exclusions: EXCLUDE any facility that does not have Full Time/sessional  doctors

name: PHC client seen by professional nurse
definition: A PHC client of any age consulted and or treated by a professional nurse (PN) for a Primary Health Care service
definitionExtended: Any client seen by a Professional nurse should be counted. Each client is counted every time they are seen by a Professional Nurse, even if a client is seen by more than one PN per day or client visit facility more than once per day and seen by a PN
useAndContext: Monitor PN workload
inclusions:
INCLUDE clients seen for preventative, promotive and curative services

INCLUDE clients seen by PN that issue CCMDD medication at facility that is also a CCMDD site
exclusions:
EXCLUDE telephonic consultations with clients

EXCLUDE clients seen by other categories of staff

name: PHC headcount 10-19 years
definition: Adolescents and youth 10-19 years old seen for Primary Health Care
definitionExtended: Count each client once for each day they appear at the facility, regardless of the number of services provided on that day; If the client is recorded as a headcount at the registration point, and the client then leaves the facility voluntarily without receiving the service that he or she is supposed to receive, a headcount can be recorded; Count all clients who access the facility for preventive, promotive, curative and rehabilitative services at a facility or with a chronic disease for whom medication is collected at the facility
useAndContext: Monitors PHC access and utilisation for clients 10-19 years
inclusions: INCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility to get feedback on any diagnostic tests done; INCLUDE clients whose medication was collected by a Home Community Based Care (HCBC worker or family member or friend as a headcount registered at the registration point; INCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility to submit sputum samples produced outside of the facility and or sputum samples produced at facility with assistance of health professional; INCLUDE a DOTS visit to the facility (but not to the community, workplace or home); INCLUDE clients who come to collect chronic medication dispensed by the facility itself (excluding CCMDD/ CDU medication) or clients using fast lines, or those to be seen by ADHERENCE counsellor at the facility; INCLUDE clients seen by a professional nurse appointed by a NPO and seconded to a clinic or service; INCLUDE clients who bypass the registration unit and go directly to the pharmacy to collect their own chronic medication or clients using fast lanes or those to be seen by outreach teams, or those to be seen by HIV counsellors; INCLUDE all clients on Space Fast Lane Modality (SFLA) who bypass registration
tools: Daily Reception Headcount register or HPRS

name: PHC headcount 20 years and older
definition: All individual clients 20 years and older seen for Primary Health Care services at a facility
definitionExtended: Count each client once for each day they appear at the facility, regardless of the number of services provided on that day; If the client is recorded as a headcount at the registration point, and the client then leaves the facility voluntarily without receiving the service that he or she is supposed to receive, a headcount can be recorded; Count all clients who access the facility for preventive, promotive, curative and rehabilitative services at a facility or with a chronic disease for whom medication is collected at the facility
useAndContext: Monitors PHC access and utilisation for clients 20 years and older.
inclusions: INCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility to get feedback on any diagnostic tests done; INCLUDE clients whose medication was collected by a Home Community Based Care (HCBC worker or family member or friend as a headcount registered at the registration point; INCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility to submit sputum samples produced outside of the facility and or sputum samples produced at facility with assistance of health professional; INCLUDE a DOTS visit to the facility (but not to the community, workplace or home); INCLUDE clients who come to collect chronic medication dispensed by the facility itself (excluding CCMDD/ CDU medication) or clients using fast lines, or those to be seen by ADHERENCE counsellor at the facility; INCLUDE clients seen by a professional nurse appointed by a NPO and seconded to a clinic or service; INCLUDE clients who bypass the registration unit and go directly to the pharmacy to collect their own chronic medication or clients using fast lanes or those to be seen by outreach teams, or those to be seen by HIV counsellors; INCLUDE all clients on Space Fast Lane Modality (SFLA) who bypass registration
tools: Daily Reception Headcount register or HPRS

name: PHC headcount 5-9 years
definition: All individual clients 5-9 years seen for Primary Health Care services at a facility
definitionExtended: Count each client once for each day they appear at the facility, regardless of the number of services provided on that day; If the client is recorded as a headcount at the registration point, and the client then leaves the facility voluntarily without receiving the service that he or she is supposed to receive, a headcount can be recorded; Count all clients who access the facility for preventive, promotive, curative and rehabilitative services at a facility or with a chronic disease for whom medication is collected at the facility
useAndContext: Monitors PHC access and utilisation for children 5-9 years.
inclusions: INCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility to get feedback on any diagnostic tests done; INCLUDE clients whose medication was collected by a Home Community Based Care (HCBC worker or family member or friend as a headcount registered at the registration point; INCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility to submit sputum samples produced outside of the facility and or sputum samples produced at facility with assistance of health professional; INCLUDE a DOTS visit to the facility (but not to the community, workplace or home); INCLUDE clients who come to collect chronic medication dispensed by the facility itself (excluding CCMDD/ CDU medication) or clients using fast lines, or those to be seen by ADHERENCE counsellor at the facility; INCLUDE clients seen by a professional nurse appointed by a NPO and seconded to a clinic or service; INCLUDE clients who bypass the registration unit and go directly to the pharmacy to collect their own chronic medication or clients using fast lanes or those to be seen by outreach teams, or those to be seen by HIV counsellors; INCLUDE all clients on Space Fast Lane Modality (SFLA) who bypass registration
tools: Daily Reception Headcount register or HPRS

name: PHC headcount under 5 years
definition: All individual clients not yet reached five years (60 months) seen for Primary Health Care services at a facility
definitionExtended: Count each client once for each day they appear at the facility, regardless of the number of services provided on that day. If the client is recorded as a headcount at the registration point and the client then leaves the facility voluntarily without receiving the service that he or she is supposed to receive, a headcount can be recorded. If infant is delivered at the facility, the infant should be countered as a headcount because services like immunisation, MUAC, PCR testing at birth and full baby examination, etc. are provided to that infant. Record only a sick child who is brought to the facility for treatment or a child with a chronic disease for whom medication is collected at the facility
useAndContext: Monitors PHC access and utilisation for children under 5 years.
exclusions:
EXCLUDE children seen by health professionals of the facility part of an outreach team at another health facility
EXCLUDE national campaign (EPI or <5 years, HPV vaccination) headcounts
EXCLUDE cases where a client visits a facility just to make an appointment (e.g. transport or OPD or specialist appointments)
EXCLUDE clients seen in CCMDD site at facility
tools: Daily Reception Headcount register or HPRS

name: PHC professional nurse clinical work days
definition: The actual work days by Professional Nurses used to perform clinical services
useAndContext: Monitor PN workload
inclusions:
INCLUDE work days of nurses seconded by District Support Partners 
INCLUDE workdays of nurses doing outreach e.g. specialised psychiatric Nurses, ophthalmic Nurses, etc.
INCLUDE work days of PHC staff working in MOUs
exclusions:
EXCLUDE days spent on training courses

EXCLUDE days spent at meetings

EXCLUDE days spent on administrative issues only (not dealing with clients in that time)

EXCLUDE days not worked (e.g. leave, public holidays)

EXCLUDE travelling time for mobile services

name: PHC public/sessional doctor clinical work days
definition: The actual work days by doctors employed in the public sector/sessional doctors employed on contract in the public sector rendering a general clinical service
useAndContext: Monitoring of services rendered by public full time / sessional doctors to consult PHC clients in public health facilities in accordance with the NHI objectives to increase doctor coverage
inclusions:
INCLUDE patient seen for renewal of prescriptions
 
INCLUDE curative and preventative services

INCLUDE other work days of Doctors seconded by DSPs
exclusions:
EXCLUDE any facility that does not have public full Time /sessional private doctors
 
EXCLUDE Dentist work days 

EXCLUDE Psychologist work days

EXCLUDE work days by specialist doctors e.g. Psychiatrist

name: Fixed CHC
definition: A fixed CHC that renders comprehensive integrated PHC services that is open 24 hours, 7 days per week, and Fixed CDC is open up to 12 hours per day.
definitionExtended: None
useAndContext: This semi-permanent data element will have the value 1 for each CHC that fulfils the criteria
inclusions: None
exclusions: None

name: Fixed CDC
definition: A facility which is not open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, but at which a broad range of Primary Health Care services are provided. It also offers accident & emergencies but not midwifery services or surgery under general anaesthesia
definitionExtended: None
useAndContext: This semi-permanent data element will have the value 1 for each CDC that fulfils the criteria
inclusions: None
exclusions: None

name: Fixed clinic
definition: An appropriately permanently equipped facility at which a range of Primary Health Care services are provided. It is open at least 8 hours a day at least 4 days a week
definitionExtended: None
useAndContext: This semi-permanent data element will have the value 1 for each clinic that fulfils the criteria
inclusions: None
exclusions: None

name: Fixed PHC facility obtained Ideal Health Facility (IHF) status, as determined by the PPTICRM, Peer Reviews (PRs) or Peer Reviews Updates (PRUs)
shortname: Fixed PHC facility obtained Ideal Health Facility
definition: Sum of fixed PHC health facilities that have obtained *Ideal health facility (IHF) status with peer or peer review updates in current financial year + fixed PHC health facilities that had obtained IHF status in previous financial years during peer and peer review updates that have retained their IHF status in the current financial year. *Obtained Silver/Gold/Platinum status
definitionExtended: The Status Determination (SD) conducted according to the Ideal Clinic Cycle. The SD should be conducted  in the first quarter of the financial year by the facility manager and in the second quarter by the PPTICRMs. Inter-districts Peer Reviews are conducted during the third quarter by the PPTICRMs; and during the fourth quarter Peer Reviews Updates, by those who have been assigned the PRU role for specific facilities that did not achieve the status during PRs. In case all the facilities have been previously peer reviewed and have lost their status during the PPTICRM SD, the PPTICRM should be assigned the PRU role in the fourth quarter.
useAndContext: Monitors whether PHC health establishments are measuring their own level of compliance with standards in order to close gaps and improve the quality of health services
inclusions: Fixed clinics, CHCs and CDCs
exclusions: Satellite and mobile clinics,  District/Regional/ Tertiary/Specialised hospitals

name: Ideal clinic status determination conducted by PPTICRM (fixed clinic/CHC/CDC)
shortname: Ideal clinic status determination conducted by PPT
definition: Number of Ideal clinic status determinations conducted by Perfect Permanent Teams for Ideal Clinic Realisation and Maintenance (PPTICRM) according to the Ideal Clinic manual
definitionExtended: A determination conducted according to the Ideal Clinic manual. The status determination should be done in the first and secord quarters of a financial year. Record 1 (one) regardless of the number of determinations conducted during the reporting period and 0 (Zero) if no determination was conducted. Do not leave this field blank
useAndContext: Monitors whether PHC health establishments are measuring their own level of compliance with standards in order to close gaps in preparation for an external assessment by the Office of Health Standards Compliance
inclusions: None
exclusions: None

name: Antenatal 1st visit 20 weeks or later
definition: A first visit by a pregnant woman to a health facility that occurs 20 weeks or later after her last menstrual period or to primarily receive antenatal care according to BANC. The first antenatal visit is often referred to as a ‘booking visit’
definitionExtended: The  first visit will  be referred as such  even is the pregnancy is advanced long after 20 weeks as long as it is the first visit for a woman for that pregnancy. The actual protocol followed during the visit might vary between provinces but it should include: all relevant blood tests e.g., HIV, syphilis, haemoglobin etc, other screening procedures,  counselling and health promotion, maternal vaccinations or treatment where relevant
useAndContext: Monitors early utilisation of antenatal services
inclusions: INCLUDE patients referred  to facility from private  health providers
exclusions: EXCLUDE patients who opt for Termination of pregnancy
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register
Tick Register OPD

name: Antenatal 1st visit before 20 weeks
definition: A first visit by a pregnant woman to a health facility that occurs before 20 weeks after her last menstrual period to primarily receive antenatal care according to BANC. The first antenatal visit is often referred to as a ‘booking visit’
definitionExtended: The actual protocol followed during the visit might vary but it should include relevant screening procedures, laboratory tests (e.g. for syphilis), counselling and health promotion (often done in groups).   The actual protocol followed during the visit might vary between provinces but it should include : all relevant blood tests  e.g. HIV, syphilis, haemoglobin etc, other screening procedures,  counselling and health promotion,maternal vaccinations or treatment where relevant
useAndContext: Monitors early utilisation of antenatal services
inclusions: None
exclusions: None
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register
Tick Register OPD

name: Antenatal already on ART at 1st visit
shortname: Antenatal already on ART at 1st visit
definition: HIV positive antenatal client who is on ART at the time of her first antenatal visit
definitionExtended: None
useAndContext: Monitors the women who fell pregnant while on ART
inclusions: INCLUDE pregnant women who were previously initiated on ART and stopped for any reason
exclusions: EXCLUDE pregnant women who are newly diagnosed and newly  initiated on ART
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register
Tick Register OPD

name: Antenatal HIV re-test
definition: Antenatal clients who tested negative for HIV during an earlier antenatal visit and were re-tested for HIV during the pregnancy
definitionExtended: Each antenatal client whose previous HIV test was negative should be re-tested at every BANC  visit  during pregnancy to detect late sero-converters
useAndContext: Monitor HIV retesting among ANC clients to identify clients who seroconverted after previous negative test
inclusions: INCLUDE all ANC clients previously tested HIV negative
exclusions: EXCLUDE ANC clients who tested HIV positive
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register
Tick Register OPD

name: Antenatal HIV 1st test
definition: Antenatal client who was tested for the first time during her current pregnancy
definitionExtended: Each antenatal client who is not known HIV positive should be tested during her 1st antenatal visit
useAndContext: Monitors implementation of PMTCT guidelines in terms of ART initiation of eligible HIV positive antenatal clients
inclusions: INCLUDE ANC adolescents (15 to 19 years) tested for HIV
exclusions:
EXCLUDE HIV re-tests

EXCLUDE HIV tests done prior to current pregnancy
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register
Tick Register OPD

name: Antenatal HIV 1st test positive
definition: Antenatal clients who tested positive for the first HIV test done during the current pregnancy
definitionExtended: Count ONLY once on the day the HIV test was confirmed positive
useAndContext: Monitors implementation of PMTCT guidelines in terms of ART initiation of eligible HIV positive antenatal clients
inclusions: INCLUDE ANC adolescents (15 to 19 years) tested positive for HIV
exclusions:
EXCLUDE HIV positive re-test

EXCLUDE HIV tests done previously confirmed positive
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register
Tick Register OPD

name: Antenatal HIV retest positive
definition: Antenatal client who was tested positive for HIV at 2nd or later test after testing negative for HIV during an earlier antenatal visit during the current pregnancy (including and ending at delivery)
definitionExtended: Count ONLY once on the day the HIV test was done
useAndContext: Monitors implementation of PMTCT guidelines in terms of ART initiation of eligible HIV positive antenatal clients
inclusions: INCLUDE ANC adolescents (15-19 years) testing positive on HIV re-test
exclusions: EXCLUDE ANC HIV positive first test
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register
Tick Register OPD

name: Antenatal known HIV positive but NOT on ART at 1st visit
shortname: Antenatal known HIV positive but NOT on ART at 1st
definition: All ANC clients who previously tested HIV positive but were not initiated on ART and are presenting at Health Facility for their first ANC visit
definitionExtended: None
useAndContext: Monitors the  HIV positive women who fell pregnant while  NOT on ART
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE antenatal clients previously on ART but not on ART at 1st visit
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register
Tick Register OPD

name: ANC ART start
definition: HIV positive antenatal clients who were initiated on ART during their current pregnancy
definitionExtended: This data element monitors ANC clients who tested HIV positive in the current pregnancy and are initiated on ART
useAndContext: Monitors linkage of HIV positive pregnant women to ART
inclusions: INCLUDE Adolescent antenatal client start on ART
exclusions: Exclude the clients who were previously initiated on ART
tools: ART clinical record captured in Tier.Net

name: Born alive before arrival at facility
shortname: Born alive before arrival at facility
definition: A childbirth (live or stillborn) that occurs outside of a healthcare facility, such as at home or en route to the hospital, reached a health facility within 72 hours for further care.
definitionExtended: The assumption is that the mother will proceed to the (nearest) facility  soon or a few hours after birth.  (BBA) should only be counted when the foetus is of 26 or more weeks gestational age and/or weighs 500g or more. Multiple births are counted as several live births
useAndContext: Monitors the babies born before the mother arrives at a health facility
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE infants weighing less than 500g
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; Tick Register Casualty

name: Death in facility 0-6 days
definition: Death of a live born neonate within 6 completed days after birth is known as an early neonatal death
definitionExtended: The neonatal period is exactly four weeks or 28 completed days, with the first 6 completed days called the early neonatal period. The assumption is that  neonates who get delivered in other facilities and due to complex illness get referred to next level of care, when they die they get counted as infacility death of that particular facility
useAndContext: Monitors trends in neonatal deaths in health facilities. Deaths of neonates 0 to 6 days is in line with WHO definition of early neonatal death.
inclusions:
INCLUDE  as early neonatal deaths when the foetus is of 26 or more weeks gestational age and/or weighs 500g or more

INCLUDE all infants born in the facility that die within 6 completed days after birth, even if they are not admitted separate from their mothers

INCLUDE neonates born in another facility but admitted in the facility after birth
exclusions:
EXCLUDE infants who died outside the facility (e.g. dead on arrivals)

EXCLUDE stillbirths
tools: Midnight Census, Inpatient sick neonatal admission register (ISNAR), Birth Register, Paeds Register

name: Death in facility 7-28 days
definition: A death of a live born neonate between 7 to 28 completed days after birth is known as a late neonatal death
definitionExtended: The neonatal period is exactly four weeks or 28 completed days, with the period from 7 to 28 completed days called the late neonatal period
useAndContext: Monitors trends in neonatal deaths in health facilities. Deaths of neonates 7 to 28 days is in line with WHO definition of late neonatal death.
inclusions: INCLUDE neonate 7-28 days who died inside a health facility;
exclusions: EXCLUDE infants who died outside the facility (e.g. dead on arrivals)
tools: Midnight Census, Inpatient sick neonatal admission register (ISNAR), Birth Register, Paeds Register

name: Delivery 10-14 years in facility
definition: Delivery where the mother is 10-14 years old. These deliveries are done in facilities under the supervision of trained medical/nursing staff
definitionExtended: Multiple births should be counted as 1 delivery and 2 (or more) births irrespective of the method of delivery. In the case of multiple births, where 1 (or more) neonate(s) is a vaginal delivery and 1 (or more) by Caesarean section-count/report the more complex method i.e. Caesarean delivery. On average, expect multiple births to be around 15 percent of the total-usually higher in referral hospitals and lower in Midwife Obstetrics Units due to referral of clients expecting twins or triplets
useAndContext: Monitors the proportion of deliveries in facility by teenagers.
inclusions: None
exclusions:
EXCLUDE deliveries taking place before arrival at the facility (BBAs) or home deliveries

EXCLUDE termination of pregnancy

EXCLUDE miscarriage

EXCLUDE deliveries of below 500g birth weight
tools: Midnight Census, Inpatient sick neonatal admission register (ISNAR), Birth Register, Paeds Register

name: Delivery 15-19 years in facility
definition: Delivery where the mother is 15-19 years old. These deliveries are done in facilities under the supervision of trained medical/nursing staff
definitionExtended: Multiple births should be counted as 1 delivery and 2 (or more) births irrespective of the method of delivery. In the case of multiple births, where 1 (or more) neonate(s) is a vaginal delivery and 1 (or more) by Caesarean section-count/report the more complex method i.e. Caesarean delivery. On average, expect multiple births to be around 15 percent of the total-usually higher in referral hospitals and lower in Midwife Obstetrics Units due to referral of clients expecting twins or triplets
useAndContext: Monitors the proportion of deliveries in facility by adolescents
inclusions: None
exclusions:
EXCLUDE deliveries taking place before arrival at the facility (BBAs) or home deliveries 

EXCLUDE termination of pregnancy

EXCLUDE miscarriage 

EXCLUDE deliveries of below 500g birth weight

name: Delivery 20 years and older in facility
shortname: Delivery 20 years and older in facility
definition: Delivery where the mother is 20 years and older. These deliveries are done in facilities under the supervision of trained medical/nursing staff
definitionExtended: Multiple births should be counted as 1 delivery and 2 (or more) births irrespective of the method of delivery. In the case of multiple births, where 1 (or more) neonate(s) is a vaginal delivery and 1 (or more) by Caesarean section-count/report the more complex method i.e. Caesarean delivery. On average, expect multiple births to be around 15 percent of the total-usually higher in referral hospitals and lower in Midwife Obstetrics Units due to referral of clients expecting twins or triplets
useAndContext: Monitors accessibility of maternity and obstetric services.

name: Delivery by caesarean section
definition: A Caesarean section delivery in facility is the removal of the foetus, placenta and membranes by means of an incision through the abdominal and uterine walls-obviously only done in health facilities by doctors
definitionExtended: The subdivisions of ceasarean section include both the emergency C/section and the elective C/sections however all counted as delivery by ceasarean section.
useAndContext: Monitors access to Caesarean section (and other surgery) as well as use of resources at delivery facilities.
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE hysterectomies

name: Infant PCR test around 10 weeks
definition: Infants born to HIV positive woman who are PCR tested around 10 weeks   ( between 6 and 18 weeks)
definitionExtended: All PCR tests done on HIV exposed infants from 6 to 18 weeks after birth can be counted. PCR tests done around 10 weeks allow sufficient time to test HIV exposed infants as a follow up test from birth.
useAndContext: Monitors  access to HIV testing for HIV exposed infants
inclusions: INCLUDE PCR tests done from 6 to 18 weeks after birth
exclusions:
EXCLUDE confirmatory PCR tests done

EXCLUDE tests for infants who had
positive results in the birth test
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; HTS module in TIER.Net, Paediatric Ward Register

name: Infant PCR test at birth
definition: Infants born to HIV positive mothers who are PCR tested at birth
definitionExtended: Ideally HIV exposed infants must be tested within the first 7 days after birth. In cases where infants have been missed, any test done before 6 weeks is still counted as a birth PCR test. This data element will fast track diagnosis of HIV exposed infants and initiation into treatment as recommended by the latest National consolidated guidelines for PMTCT and management of HIV in children, adolescents and adults.
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the National consolidated HIV policy guidelines
inclusions: INCLUDE 1st PCR tests done before 6 weeks after birth
exclusions: EXCLUDE confirmatory PCR tests done
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; Delivery Register, Paediatric Ward Register

name: Infant PCR test positive at birth
shortname: Infant PCR test positive at birth
definition: Infants born to HIV positive mothers who tested PCR positive at birth
definitionExtended: Ideally HIV exposed infants must be tested within the first 7 days after birth. In cases where infants have been missed, positive results on tests done before 6 weeks is still counted as PCR positive tests at birth. Infants who tested positive need to be linked to care to ensure they are initiated on treatment as per the latest National consolidated HIV policy guidelines
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the National consolidated HIV policy guidelines
inclusions: INCLUDE PCR positive results from 1st PCR tests done before 6 weeks after birth
exclusions: EXCLUDE confirmatory PCR positive results
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; Delivery Register; Tick Register Casualty; Paediatric Ward Register

name: Infant PCR test positive around 10 weeks
shortname: Infant PCR test positive around 10 weeks
definition: Infants born to HIV positive woman with PCR positive results around 10 weeks ( between 6 and 18 weeks)
definitionExtended: All PCR positive results on tests done on HIV exposed infants from 6 to 18 weeks after birth can be counted. Infants who tested positive need to be linked to care to ensure they are initiated on treatment as per the latest National consolidated HIV policy guidelines
useAndContext: Monitors Vertical transmission of HIV at 10 weeks
inclusions: INCLUDE PCR positive results from PCR tests done from 6 to 18 weeks after birth
exclusions: EXCLUDE confirmatory PCR positive results
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; HTS  module in TIER.Net, Paediatric Ward Register

name: Live birth in facility
definition: Live birth resulting from a delivery in a facility
definitionExtended: Live birth is the complete expulsion or extraction from its mother of a product of conception, irrespective of the duration of the pregnancy, which, after such separation, breathes or shows any other evidence of life, such as beating of the heart, pulsation of the umbilical cord, or definite movement of involuntary muscles, whether or not the umbilical cord has been cut or the placenta is attached. The weight range relates to the weight of the infant immediately after delivery. Count the number of infants born when twins or multiple births occur. A live birth should not be admitted as an inpatient but as a Live-in infant. When live-in infants require treatment they must be admitted as inpatients. Live births should only be counted when the foetus is of 26 or more weeks gestational age and/or weighs 500g or more
useAndContext: Monitors stillbirth trends
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE miscarriages and TOPs

name: Live birth to HIV positive woman
shortname: Live birth to HIV positive woman
definition: Live birth to a woman known to be HIV positive at delivery
definitionExtended: Includes infants born before arrival (BBA) at health facilities and infants born outside health facilities. Live births should only be counted when the foetus is of 26 or more weeks gestational age and/or weighs 500g or more. Live births of women with unknown HIV status at delivery and tested during or after delivery and found to be HIV positive should also be counted
useAndContext: Monitors implementation of PMTCT guidelines
inclusions: INCLUDE infants born before arrival (BBA) at health facilities and infants born outside health facilities if they arrive within 72 hours of birth
exclusions: None

name: Live birth under 2500 g in facility
shortname: Live birth under 2500 g in facility
definition: Infants born alive weighing less than 2500 g regardless  gestational age  as proportion of total Infants born alive in health facilities (Low birth weight)
definitionExtended: The risk of low birth weight most often  is related to gestational age i.e. the time in utero and the fetal well being  in utero e.g.g .nutritional endowment from the mother. Other categories of low birth weight include preterm appropriate for gestational age LBW, term appropriate for gestational age LBW (small for gestational age/SGA)
useAndContext:
Monitors trends in infants with low birth weight to improve maternal nutritional status; guarantee adequate 
maternal services and care before, during and after birth; and strengthen social support
inclusions: None
exclusions: None

name: Maternal death in facility
definition: Maternal death in facility is death  of a woman in a health facility occurring during pregnancy, childbirth or puerperium within 42 days of termination of pregnancy. These  should be collected  and reported in all units of a health facility
definitionExtended: Maternal death  occurring during pregnancy, childbirth and puerperium (within 42 days of delivery or termination of pregnancy), irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy and the cause of death, with the exception of coincidental deaths (such as lightning strike, mass shooting victim). However, without any exception, all deaths occurring during pregnancy, childbirth and puerperium must by law be notified to the Provincial department of health
useAndContext: This is a proxy for the population-based maternal mortality ratio, aimed at monitoring trends in health facilities between official surveys. The reporting of maternal deaths is a mandatory legal obligation  by health facilities, to record and notify the death,  undergo maternal death review  processes  to assess  related causes of maternal mortality in the country
inclusions: INCLUDE maternal deaths in EMS transit between facilities i.e those occurring enroute from referring facility to a receiving facility . When the woman dies before reaching the receiving facility, count the death as a death in facility at the referring health facility. If diagnosis of death is only made after arriving at the receiving facility, count the death as a death at the receiving facility. Include  women who died in the facility, irrespective of where the baby was born.
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Maternal Death outside the facility (home deaths, DOA  from the  community

EXCLUDE Coincidental death  category of death during pregnancy, childbirth and the puerperium (DDPCP) which are strictly not maternal deaths i.e. death of a woman that occurred as a result of  accident, lightning strike, crushed by a collapsing building, mass shooting victim etc
collectionPoints:
Inpatient facility and Casualty/OPD
PHC Facilities
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register, Ward Tick register OPD,
Delivery and ICU Register, Midnight Census

name: Mother postnatal visit within 6 days after delivery
shortname: Mother postnatal visit within 6 days after deliver
definition: Mothers who received postnatal care within 6 days after delivery as proportion of deliveries in health facilities
definitionExtended: The visit can be at a PHC facility or a postnatal home visit by facility staff and include mother who are hospitalised within 6 day. The purpose of the visit is for a postnatal check-up. Count only the first visit after delivery. The postnatal protocol should be followed. Although there may be slight differences, this element serves as a proxy for infant postnatal visit within 6 days after delivery. Mothers who received postnatal care within 6 days at any point of care within the health facility, should ONLY be recorded in the postnatal register.
useAndContext: Monitors access to and utilisation of postnatal services. May be more than 100% in areas with low delivery in facility rates if many mothers who delivered outside health  facilities used postnatal visits within 6 days after delivery  period.Since some delivered mothers may still be in a hospital, or may come in for some reason  within the period 3-6 days,  postnatal care service received whilst in hospital  during that period  should be captured and  recorded.
inclusions: This should include Ceasarean Section Mothers, sick mothers admitted in hospital, lodger mothers, visiting mothers or those in the KMC Unit
exclusions: None
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register, Post-natal register, Maternity Register, OPD register

name: Still birth in facility
definition: Still born infants delivered in a health facility
definitionExtended:
Still birth is death prior to the complete expulsion or extraction from its mother of a product of conception.
The death is indicated by the fact that after such separation the foetus does not breathe or show any evidence of life, such as beating of the heart, pulsation of the umbilical cord or definite movement of the involuntary muscles. Still births should only be counted when the foetus is of 26 or more weeks gestational age and/or weighs 500g or more. A still-born foetus might have been dead for a while (macerated) or died just before or during expulsion or extraction (fresh) from its mother. Multiple births are counted as several stillbirths (or as a combination of live and stillbirths, if one foetus is alive and another not)
useAndContext: Monitors stillbirth trends
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE still births less than 500g

useAndContext: Monitors  access to HIV testing for HIV exposed infants
inclusions: INCLUDE PCR tests done from 19 to 36 weeks after birth
exclusions: EXCLUDE infants who tested  PCR positive at birth and 10 weeks

name: Mental health involuntary admission
definition: Client admitted for mental health conditions in terms of section 33 of the Mental Health Care Act No 17 of 2002
definitionExtended: These are clients who are admitted and provided with care, treatment and rehabilitation without their informed consent and due to their mental health status are refusing/ unwilling to be admitted and receive the required care, treatment and rehabilitation. The data element should be collected at all hospitals with designated psychiatric beds or wards, specialised psychiatric hospitals and hospitals listed to provide the 72-hour assessment contemplated in section 34 of the Mental Health Care Act.  These admissions have to be monitored and controlled in view of the human rights issues risks associated
useAndContext: Monitors involuntary admissions in terms of the Mental Health Care Act 17 of 2002.
inclusions:
INCLUDE clients that were originally admitted under section 9 (c) (emergency admission without consent) and section 40 (1) (handed over by members of the SAPS) of the Mental Health Care Act No 17 of 2002 as soon as an application for them is made in terms of Section 33 of the Mental Health Care Act, 2002

INCLUDE clients admitted involuntary directly from community to specialised psychiatric hospitals
exclusions:
EXCLUDE voluntary, assisted as well as emergency admissions as well as admissions in terms of Section 40(1) of the Mental Health Care Act, 2002 until an application is made for them in terms of Section 33 of the Mental Health Care Act, 2002E

EXCLUDE transfers in of already classified involuntary users
collectionPoints:
General hospitals with mental health units or wards

Specialised psychiatric hospitals and care and rehabilitation centres

Hospitals that are listed to conduct 72 hour assessments of involuntary mental health care users.

name: Patient Safety Incident case closed
definition: Patient Safety Incident (PSI) case closed within the reporting month
definitionExtended: Patient safety incident: is an event or circumstance that could have resulted, or did result, in unnecessary harm to a patient. The use of the word “unnecessary” in this definition recognizes that errors, violation, patient abuse and deliberately unsafe acts occur in healthcare. These are considered incidents. Incident: An incident can be a reportable circumstance, near miss, no harm incident or harmful incident (adverse event). Reportable circumstance: is a situation in which there was significant potential for harm, but no incident occurred. Near miss: is an incident which did not reach the patient. No harm incident: is one in which an event reached a patient but no discernible harm resulted. Harmful incident: is an incident that results in harm to a patient. Adverse event: harm related to medical management, in contrast to disease complications or underlying disease. Medical management includes all aspects of care from interaction with health care provider to discharge of a patient from medical treatment or health care facility.
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of the National policy to manage patient safety incidents
inclusions: None
exclusions: None

Incident: An incident can be a reportable circumstance, near miss, no harm incident or harmful incident (adverse event). Reportable circumstance: is a situation in which there was significant potential for harm, but no incident occurred. Near miss: is an incident which did not reach the patient. No harm incident: is one in which an event reached a patient but no discernible harm resulted. Harmful incident: is an incident that results in harm to a patient. Adverse event: harm related to medical management, in contrast to disease complications or underlying disease. useAndContext:

name: ANC syphilis 1st test
definition: ANC client tested for syphilis for the first time during current pregnancy
definitionExtended: This data element represents the count of individual antenatal clients who undergo a syphilis test for the very first time during their current, ongoing pregnancy. It is a critical measurement of the coverage of antenatal syphilis screening programs. All pregnant women should be screened for syphilis at their first antenatal visit to ensure timely treatment and prevent congenital syphilis. This data element does not include repeat tests or tests conducted during prior pregnancies
useAndContext: Monitoring the proportion of pregnant women screened for syphilis for the first time during the current pregnancy is vital to assessing progress towards the elimination of congenital syphilis. This data informs the effectiveness of screening programs, identifies gaps in services, and allows for targeted interventions to increase testing coverage and treatment rates. The data is crucial for the planning, implementation, and evaluation of public health interventions aimed at reducing the incidence of syphilis during pregnancy
inclusions: INCLUDE Antenatal clients who undergo their initial (first time) syphilis test within the timeframe of their  pregnancy, regardless of gestational age at time of test
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Any repeat syphilis tests conducted during the current pregnancy

EXCLUDE Syphilis tests performed prior to the commencement of the current pregnancy

EXCLUDE Post-natal syphilis tests
tools:
Maternity case record & Pink folder.  PHC Comprehensive Tick Register;
Tick Register OPD; Maternity register

name: ANC Syphilis 1st test positive
definition: Number of pregnant women testing positive for syphilis on their initial syphilis test during their current antenatal care (ANC) visits.
definitionExtended: This data element counts the number of pregnant women attending ANC who receive a positive result on their first syphilis test conducted during their current pregnancy, regardless of previous syphilis testing history in past pregnancies. This count only includes positive test results from the initial syphilis test for each woman in the current pregnancy.
useAndContext: Syphilis testing is a vital tool to detect and then treat syphilis among pregnant women and to prevent the mother to child transmission of syphilis. Monitoring syphilis tests will contribute towards the goal of eliminating congenital syphilis
inclusions:
INCLUDE Positive syphilis test results from the first test performed during the current pregnancy at the first ANC visit

INCLUDE Positive results from RPR syphilis tests

INCLUDE Positive results from any ANC client who is tested for the first time within the current pregnancy
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Syphilis-positive results identified during repeat tests during the same pregnancy

EXCLUDE Syphilis-positive results identified during previous pregnancies

EXCLUDE  Syphilis-positive results if the syphilis test was not performed during the first ANC visit

EXCLUDE Syphilis results from clients who are not pregnant

EXCLUDE Indeterminate or invalid test results
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register;
Tick Register OPD

name: ANC syphilis re-test
definition: ANC client retested for syphilis during their current pregnancy
definitionExtended: This data element quantifies the number of antenatal care (ANC) clients who receive a re-test for syphilis during their current pregnancy, after having previously tested negative for syphilis earlier in the same pregnancy. This re-testing is performed to detect potential syphilis seroconversions. Each instance of re-testing for an individual client should be recorded. This re-testing should adhere to the frequency and timing guidelines outlined in the relevant national or local vertical transmission prevention (VTP) guidelines. This data element does not include initial syphilis tests performed during the first ANC visit or subsequent re-tests for clients who previously tested positive for syphilis
useAndContext: Monitoring the scale-up of screening and treatment for pregnant women remains paramount to measuring progress towards the Path to elimination goal. Measuring the number of pregnant women affected by syphilis is crucial to guide the capacity of health systems to strengthen the prevention, detection and treatment of syphilis
inclusions:
INCLUDE All ANC clients who have a documented negative syphilis test result earlier in their current pregnancy and are subsequently re-tested for syphilis (regardless of the result of the re-test)

INCLUDE Each instance of a client being re-tested should count as a separate event
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Initial syphilis tests performed during the first ANC visit

EXCLUDE Re-tests for clients who have a documented positive syphilis test during their current pregnancy (even if they subsequently test negative during re-testing)

EXCLUDE Syphilis tests performed outside of the current pregnancy
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register;
Tick Register OPD

name: ANC client syphilis retest positive
definition: Count the number of antenatal care (ANC) clients who have a documented positive syphilis diagnostic test result after having had a documented negative syphilis diagnostic test result earlier during the same pregnancy. This count is limited to the period during the current pregnancy, including through delivery
definitionExtended: This data element captures the number of antenatal clients who initially tested negative for syphilis during their current pregnancy and subsequently tested positive during a repeat syphilis diagnostic test within the same pregnancy. It tracks syphilis seroconversions, specifically the change from a negative test result to a positive test result. A repeat syphilis diagnostic test should be conducted according to national/local antenatal care (ANC) guidelines, at recommended follow-up visits. This data element includes first positive repeat tests, but not repeated tests that are also positive in the same pregnancy for the same client. This is measured up to and including delivery.
useAndContext: Monitoring the incidence of syphilis among pregnant women through data on seroconversion is critical for evaluating the effectiveness of antenatal screening programs. This data informs efforts to prevent mother-to-child transmission of syphilis and guides resource allocation for diagnostic testing and treatment. This data measures the health system's capacity to identify and treat new infections during pregnancy and contributes to the Path to Elimination goals. It also measures the infection rate in the local community.
inclusions:
INCLUDE All ANC clients who have a documented negative syphilis diagnostic test result during their current pregnancy and who subsequently have a documented positive syphilis diagnostic test result (seroconversion) during the same pregnancy

INCLUDE This includes diagnostic tests performed at any gestational age up to and including delivery in the current pregnancy

INCLUDE This measurement includes cases where repeat testing was required by the antenatal care (ANC) guidelines
exclusions:
EXCLUDE ANC clients who have any documented positive syphilis diagnostic test result recorded at the first visit during their current pregnancy 

EXCLUDE Cases where the tests were not performed during the current pregnancy

EXCLUDE Instances where a client has multiple positive tests after seroconversion (only the first positive is counted after the first negative test

EXCLUDE Positive re-tests for women that were initially positive for diagnosis during their current pregnancy
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick Register;
Tick Register OPD,                       Maternity case record & Pink folder

name: Antenatal client syphilis- BPG 1st Dose
definition: Syphilis positive ANC client administered the first dose of BPG
definitionExtended: This data element captures the number of antenatal clients who have: * A confirmed positive syphilis test  result during their current (index) pregnancy. * Received their first intramuscular administration of Benzathine Penicillin G (BPG), as part of syphilis treatment for this pregnancy. * The BPG dose must be administered after the positive syphilis test result for it to be included. Only the first dose of BPG is counted, within the current index pregnancy
useAndContext: This data element is essential for monitoring progress towards the elimination of congenital syphilis (CS) by tracking the coverage of timely treatment initiation among pregnant women diagnosed with active syphilis infection. Accurate measurement of BPG first-dose administration is critical for assessing the effectiveness of antenatal syphilis screening and treatment programs, guiding resource allocation, and informing health policies to reduce vertical child transmission of syphilis (MTCT). The data also helps understand the cascade of care from screening to prevention of congenital syphilis. This data is a critical indicator for program evaluation and reporting
inclusions:
INCLUDE Antenatal clients who have a positive syphilis test result  during their current index pregnancy 

INCLUDE Antenatal clients who received their first intramuscular injection of BPG for syphilis treatment after positive syphilis test result, and during their current pregnancy.

INCLUDE The positive syphilis test result from their initial routine test, or from a re-test based on risk factors or prior negative testing
exclusions:
EXCLUDE BPG dose 2 or BPG dose 3 (only BPG 1st dose is included)

EXCLUDE BPG administered for treatment of a different infection or for a different indication other than syphilis treatment

EXCLUDE BPG dose one administered during a previous pregnancy

EXCLUDE Clients who have tested positive but have not yet received BPG

EXCLUDE Clients who had a negative test and were treated prophylactically

EXCLUDE Any administration of BPG that was not intramuscular
tools: Maternity case record & Pink folder. PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; Tick Register OPD

definitionExtended: The policy states that women must be screened for cervical cancer at least 3 times in a lifetime. Women should be screened every 10 years from the age of 30 years. Only smears and liquid base screenings done for women in the specified age category should be counted here. The smear must be sufficient to enable quality screening (i.e. include endocervical cells)

name: Total clients Start on PrEP
definition: The first time initiation of antiretroviral medicine by clients who are HIV negative before they are exposed to HIV, in order to prevent an HIV infection during the reporting period of all ages and gender
definitionExtended: This data element captures the unduplicated count of individuals newly starting PrEP within the specified reporting period. "First time" refers to the first instance of PrEP initiation ever, not just the first time within the current reporting period. Individuals who discontinued PrEP and are restarting it are considered new initiations if they are restarting it in the current reporting period. Initiation includes the provision of a PrEP prescription and dispensing or provision of PrEP medication within the reporting period.
useAndContext: NOTE that clients who have an outcome in the specified month or months previous should not be counted in this total
inclusions:
INCLUDE Individuals initiating PrEP for the first time, regardless of age, gender, or risk group

INCLUDE Individuals initiating PrEP after a period of discontinuation, if the initiation occurs within the reporting period

INCLUDE Individuals receiving PrEP through any approved service delivery model (e.g., clinic-based, community-based, telehealth)

INCLUDE Clients who receive PrEP prescriptions but delayed dispensing for some time
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Individuals already on PrEP at the beginning of the reporting period (i.e., continuing users)

EXCLUDE Focus is on new initiations.Individuals who were previously on PrEP and restart PrEP outside of the current reporting period

EXCLUDE Individuals who receive PrEP counseling or HIV testing but do not initiate PrEP during the reporting period
tools: PrEP clinical record captured on TIER.NET

name: EMS P1 rural response under 60 minutes
definition: P1 responses in a rural area where the response time was under 60 minutes
definitionExtended: P1 (Priority 1) refer to emergency calls where the patient has life-threatening injuries or illnesses and urgently need medical management at an appropriate medical facility, These calls require urgent response by an ambulance in a rural area within 60 minutes of the call being received.
useAndContext: Response time is the time it takes an ambulance to reach the patient; calculated from the time the call is received by the control room up to the time of arrival of the first emergency unit on scene
inclusions: None
exclusions: None
collectedBy: EMS personnel, Data capturers/Admin Assistants for EMS
tools: EMS Province specific data collections tools

By monitoring the number of male clients screened for an STI, one can estimate the prevalence STIs in a population, by comparing screening to MUS episodes. This will assist with the identification of areas with high burden of STIs and inform targeted prevention interventions

definitionExtended: Includes all newborns or live birth, all neonates who were initiated  within 1 hour.
useAndContext: Monitors implementation of evidence based key clinical practices for the protection, promotion and support of breatfeeding (The mother baby friendly initiative) as a standard of care in all facilities rendering deliveries. It is expected that newborns put to the breast will also receive skin-to-skin contact, and thus receive all  essential newborns care interventions.
inclusions:
INCLUDE all newborns or live birth

INCLUDE all neonates who were initiated  within 1 hour.
exclusions:
EXCLUDE BBA’s

EXCLUDE Critically ill newborns/ neonates

EXCLUDE newborns who dies after birth

name: Antenatal clients started on PrEP
definition: The number of antenatal clients, who are HIV-negative at the time of initiation, who started pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) for the first time during the designated monthly reporting period, regardless of age.
definitionExtended: This data element captures the total count of eligible pregnant women who were initiated on PrEP for the first time at a particular facility during the current reporting period. This includes clients at all gestational ages. A "first-time" start is defined as an individual who has never initiated PrEP in their lifetime. Transfers-in from another PrEP site within the same reporting period should not be counted as a new start, only initiations at your facility should be included. If transfers-in are identified, ensure client information is updated in TIER.Net but they are not included in the new start count. If there are uncertainties on initiation status, confirm in TIER.Net.
useAndContext:
The indicator measures the ongoing growth of PrEP services within the
antenatal population. This measure is critical to assess progress in the
programme’s response to the epidemic in specific geographic areas, and
the uptake and utility of PrEP among persons at substantially
increased risk of HIV infection
inclusions:
INCLUDE Antenatal clients of all ages who are confirmed HIV-negative prior to PrEP initiation

INCLUDE Clients initiating PrEP

INCLUDE Clients initiating PrEP at any point during their pregnancy
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Any antenatal client who has transferred into your facility with previous PrEP initiation during the designated reporting period

EXCLUDE Any antenatal client who has tested HIV-positive
collectionPoints: All PHCs, CHCs and PrEP sites
tools:
PHC Comprehensive Tick register 
OPD Tick register

name: INHR-TB client successfully completed treatment
definition: Clients ALL ages diagnosed with INH resistant TB who were started on treatment and have successfully completed
definitionExtended: Clients who are resistant to Isoniazid (INH) with or without resistance to other TB first line  drugs excluding rifampicin who were started on INHR-TB treatment. This includes clients who were cured and those without proof of cure at the end of the treatment period
useAndContext: Monitors TB treatment success amongst INHR-TB clients
inclusions: INCLUDE Clients confirmed with INH resistant TB started on treatment and successfully completed treatment
exclusions:
EXCLUDE clients who died whilst on treatment 
  
EXCLUDE Clients who were Lost to follow up

EXCLUDE Clients with DS TB

EXCLUDE clients with RR/MDR TB

name: INHR-TB client lost to follow-up
definition: Clients ALL AGES diagnosed with INH resistant TB who were started on treatment and were lost to follow up
definitionExtended: Loss to follow-up is defined as interruption of treatment for a period of two consecutive months or longer at any time during the treatment period.
useAndContext: Monitors trends in loss to follow-up during TB treatment period, as one of the factors suppressing the TB treatment success rate
inclusions: INCLUDE Clients started on INHR-TB treatment and who are lost to follow-up
exclusions:
EXCLUDE INHR clients who successfully completed treatment

EXCLUDE INHR clients who died

EXCLUDE all clients with DS-TB
 
EXCLUDE all clients with RR/MDR TB
tools: TB Treatment Record/ Patient Health Record

name: INHR-TB client death
definition: Clients ALL ages diagnosed with INH resistant TB who were started on treatment 12 months ago and died during the treatment period
definitionExtended: Clients who die from any cause during the course of treatment. The cause of death may not necessarily be due to TB
useAndContext: Monitors trends in death during TB treatment period, as one of the factors suppressing the TB treatment success rate
inclusions: INCLUDE Clients who were started on INHR-TB treatment and subsequently died
exclusions:
EXCLUDE INHR clients who successfully completed treatment 

EXCLUDE INHR clients who were loss to follow-up
 
EXCLUDE all clients with DS-TB 

EXCLUDE all clients with RR/MDR TB
tools: TB Treatment Record/ Patient Health Record

name: Eligible HIV positive client tested for TB using ULAM
definition: Number of eligible HIV positive clients tested for TB using urine lipoarabinomannan assay ALL AGES
definitionExtended: ULAM is one of the non-bacteriological investigations conducted to diagnose TB in HIV positive clients. Eligibility is based on the criteria as clearly outlined in the ulam guidelines. Urine LF-LAM is a point of care test used to diagnose TB from a urine sample in people living with HIV. It is used in hospitals for PLHIV who are sick and admitted as well as outpatient settings for PLHIV with a CD4 count less than 200.
useAndContext: TB is a laboratory confirmed disease, however the programme must account for all TB-diagnosed clients
inclusions: INCLUDE All PLHIV with a CD4 count less than 200 tested using urine LF-LAM. All PLHIV admitted in hospitals tested using urine LF - LAM
exclusions:
EXCLUDE HIV negative clients

EXCLUDE HIV status unknown

name: EMS clients - total
definition: Client transported by an ambulance
definitionExtended: All clients (all priorities) transported by ambulance, irrespective of the number of calls or trips
useAndContext: Measure all clients transported by an ambulance to understand the workload of EMS
inclusions: None
exclusions: None
collectedBy: EMS personnel Data capturers/Admin Assistants for EMS
tools: EMS Province specific data collections tools

name: EMS interfacility Transfers
definition: EMS inter-facility transfer where the client was transferred from one facility to another facility
definitionExtended: Measure the number of clients transferred between health facilities as opposed to the total number of clients transported
useAndContext: Measure the % of inter-facility transfers to primary responses
inclusions: None
exclusions: EXCLUDE obstetric and primary clients
collectedBy: EMS personnel Data capturers/Admin Assistants for EMS
tools: EMS Province specific data collections tools

name: HBV (0) dose given to infant born to hepatitis B positive women
definition: Hepatitis B vaccine, birth dose is given within 24 hours after birth to infants born to HBsAg POSITIVE women . The cut-off age is 2 weeks after birth.
definitionExtended: Infants who received HBV 0 (Birth) dose. The proportion of infants born to mothers who are positive for the Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) who receive the first dose of the Hepatitis B vaccine (HBV dose 0) within 24 hours of birth
useAndContext: Monitors Hepatitis B vaccine (HBV) given to infants at birth following the mother's HBsAb positive result. Monitors protection of infants against perinatal Hepatitis B virus transmission
inclusions:
INCLUDE BBAs if they are given HBV birth dose,

INCLUDE doses given to children up to 2 weeks of age
exclusions:
EXCLUDE infants born to HBsAg NEGATIVE women

EXCLUDE infants born to women with unknown Hepatitis B status
collectionPoints: All health facilities (Clinics, CHCs, Mobiles & hospitals)
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register, Maternity register & Hospital paediatric registers

name: Infant born to hepatitis B positive women
shortname: Infant born to hepatitis B positive women
definition: Children under 1 year born to Hepatitis B POSITIVE women
definitionExtended: Infants who received HBV 0 (Birth) dose, as a proportion of ANC clients tested POSITIVE for Hepatitis B. Hepatitis B is included in the DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV (Hexavalent) vaccine and given to children at 6, 10, 14 weeks and 18 months. HBV 4th dose in DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV vaccine is usually the last vaccine to be given for a child. HBV (0) is given together with BCG and OPV (0). To accommodate the 4 weeks intervals between HBV (0) and HBV (1) in DTaP-IPV-Hib-HBV vaccine, the last dose of HBV (0) should be given at 2 weeks after birth.
useAndContext: Monitors Hepatitis B vaccination (HBV) given to infants at birth following the mother’s Hepatitis B positive result. Monitors protection of infants against perinatal Hepatitis B virus transmission.
inclusions: INCLUDE infants born to Hepatitis B positive women
exclusions:
EXCLUDE infants born to Hepatitis B NEGATIVE women   

EXCLUDE infants born to women with unknow Hepatitis B status
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register, Maternity Registers & Hospital paediatric registers

name: Tdap dose 26 - 34 weeks of gestational age
definition: Tdap booster dose given to a pregnant woman at 26 to 34 weeks of gestational age. Include doses given after 34 weeks during pregnancy
definitionExtended: Tdap is tetanus plus diluted diphtheria plus acellular pertussis. The woman will receive one dose in each pregnancy at 26-34 weeks gestational age.
useAndContext: Monitors protection of pregnant women and newborns against tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis infections.  Vaccines given as part of mass vaccination campaigns should not be counted here
inclusions: INCLUDE catch-up doses given after 34 weeks DURING pregnancy
exclusions:
EXCLUDE doses given during postnatal period

EXCLUDE doses given as part of a national mass vaccination campaign
tools: PHC Comprehensive Tick Register & Maternity Registers

name: All referrals from community health workers
definition: Number of referral events received at the facility that were initiated by a Community Health Worker (CHW) during the reporting period.
definitionExtended: Count each referral event documented in the facility referral register/forms where the client resides in/comes from the facility catchment area and is referred for continuity of care (typically from community-based services). Each referral is counted once when received/recorded at the receiving facility.
useAndContext: Monitors the implementation of community-based services linked to Primary Health Care facilities in the catchment area by community health workers. Monitors and ensures a seamless user movement within the referral pathway, for continuity of care.
inclusions: Community Health Workers (CHWs)
exclusions: EXCLUDE all referrals from the District/Regional/ Tertiary hospital/Specialised hospitals, School-health Services, General Practitioners, Traditional Health Practitioners, Faith-Based Organisations, other government departments, e.g., DSD, SAPS, Correctional Services etc. Inter-disciplinary referrals within the District hospital
collectedBy: Clinicians and Registration Clerks at the Clinic/CHC/CDC

name: Pregnant women diagnosed with syphilis during their current pregnancy
shortname: A pregnant woman diagnosed with syphilis during her current pregnancy
definition: Number of pregnant women diagnosed with syphilis during their current pregnancy who have completed the full recommended treatment course of benzathine penicillin G (BPG) during the reporting period.
definitionExtended: A woman is counted if she is pregnant and has a syphilis diagnosis in the current pregnancy and has documentation of three IM doses of 2.4 MU BPG, given approximately weekly with no interval >14 days between doses, and the 3rd dose given ≥28 days before expected delivery date (where EDD is recorded). Count each woman once when completion criteria are met/recorded.
useAndContext: Syphilis treatment with BPG during pregnancy is crucial for preventing vertical transmission of syphilis and improving maternal and infant health outcomes. Consistent monitoring of BPG administration contributes directly to the goal of eliminating congenital syphilis.
inclusions:
INCLUDE All pregnant women who initiated treatment for syphilis during their current pregnancy and completed all three required BPG doses meeting the specified criteria

INCLUDE Syphilis diagnosis resulting from an initial or repeat syphilis test during this pregnancy
exclusions:
EXCLUDE Pregnant women diagnosed with syphilis during their current pregnancy who were treated with an antibiotic other than benzathine penicillin G (BPG)

EXCLUDE Pregnant women diagnosed with syphilis during their current pregnancy who did not complete all three required BPG doses

EXCLUDE Pregnant women diagnosed with syphilis during their current pregnancy who received three BPG doses with intervals greater than 14 days between any two doses

EXCLUDE Pregnant women diagnosed with syphilis during their current pregnancy who received the third BPG dose less than 28 days before her expected delivery date

EXCLUDE Pregnant women diagnosed with syphilis during their current pregnancy who received an incorrect dose of BPG
tools: Primary source: Maternity case record & Pink folder. PHC Comprehensive Tick Register; Tick Register OPD

name: Child population (6-59 months ) screened with Mid-Upper-Arm-Circumference (MUAC)
definition: Number of children aged 6–59 months who had a MUAC measurement taken (screened) by WBPHCOT/COS during the reporting period.
definitionExtended: This should assist with increasing the number of children 6 - 59 months detected  and referred  for  moderate wasting (MUAC between 11.5 cm - 12.5 cm or severe wasting  treatment (MUAC <11.5cm). Count each eligible child (6–59 months) for whom a MUAC measurement is performed and recorded during a household visit. Count once per child per day visited (if the same child is visited on different days in the month, count on each day screened; if multiple services are delivered on the same day, still count once for that day).
useAndContext: Monitors active case finding for children 6-59 with moderate wasting (MUAC from  11.5 cm to 12.5 cm) or severe wasting (MUAC between <11.5 cm), improves  coverage, early detection and referrals for children with moderate or severe wasting
inclusions: INCLUDE Individual client 6-59 months attended to by WBPHCOT in the household
exclusions: EXCLUDE clients below 6 months and above 59 months

name: MR dose 6-11 months (campaign)
definition: MR vaccine dose given to a child 6-11 months (under 1 year) of age during a mass vaccination campaign
definitionExtended: MR dose 6-11 months (campaign) coverage - TOTAL FOR CAMPAIGN. The target population estimates for 6-11 months is assumed to be 1/2 of the estimates for 0-11 months children MR dose 6-11 months (campaign) coverage - TOTAL FOR CAMPAIGN. The target population estimates for 6-11 months is assumed to be 1/2 of the estimates for 0-11 months children
useAndContext: Total coverage will grow from day to day during the campaign
inclusions: None
exclusions: None
frequency: Data collected daily and collated monthly
collectionPoints: All health facilities (Clinics, CHCs, Mobiles, ECD Centre & hospitals

name: MR dose 12-59 months (campaign)
definition: MR vaccine  dose to 12-59 months children (campaign) coverage. Since our target population estimates are for the total child population in the 12-59 months age group, it will be divided by number of campaign  days
definitionExtended: MR vaccine  dose to 12-59 months children (campaign) coverage. Since our target population estimates are for the total child population in the 12-59 months age group, it will be divided by number of campaign  days
useAndContext: Most EPI campaigns tend to run for a variable length of time in some areas, due to logistical problems or staff shortages. The daily campaign coverage figures should therefore be used with care.

exclusions: None
frequency: Data collected daily and collated monthly
